3RAx9GHjMFgM8WgmkYomdA.text: Recommended if you're in the mood of Mexican taste. Home made food, cheap price. You'll be full with 2/3 small platters for  person. Tacos are delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

GiMbouEfWhMpapvnQx1J7w.text: Completely unengaged waitress. Extremely pedestrian food. Had the pork burrito. At beast it was BORING AND TASTELESS - at worst it was completely overpriced for that little piece of tasteless meh! I hate the "the food will come out as its ready", no! We are here to eat together. Go and hire some real chefs who know how to cook such that things are ready at the same time. Pathetic, cheap ass food with high prices and poor service. I am NEVER going back. I've had better food at chipotle, and they ain't high class. This place just needs to go away!!!

ULWzdMmHOfUHzE-pVs46XA.text: The good bit: wait was reasonable for a sunday bank holiday w/e evening. Told over 1hr, but sat within ~30mins.The less good bits: bench seat covers were dirty.handed menus but not advised what was no longer available. So choice of sides were restricted to 3 of 5 (no corn or sweet potato fries!).Then handed menus for desert and again not told what wasn't available!Not sure if customers expected to be psychic.

62_KJj27paiYGXldXjcHsw.text: I'm from southern California and used to have a diet that was roughly 98% Mexican food so I'm a fan/junkie and living in London can sometimes be like visiting a rehab center in the middle of nowhere-near-Mexico.When we went to Wahaca the first time, i had my doubts, it seemed a bit of a chain which doesn't fare well to me for mexican food and the menu didn't exactly pop with selections.But, with all that said, this place is some damn good mexican food.The pork tacos are excellent, easiest the best thing I've had from them. Slow cooked, picked onions and black bean sauce.  The steak tacos were very good as well.  Guacamole could use some salt but home made looking chips were great as well.  A friend ordered the pork pibil dinner item and that looked damn good, slow cooked with rice.  I get that we are no where near Mexico and my diet has changed but this place is pretty good and will be on regular rotation now.

rCYyazFOWfnOuaZNgsCryA.text: Decent enough food, fast service. It's kind of like a Mexican version of Wagamama. The restaurant is big, staff are efficient, no waiting around for no apparent reason here.Food is good, not amazing, but solid. Better than a lot of "Mexican" restaurants in London. Pork Pibil Tacos are really good though.

2zbL_NxUzj1kI0EF0I9pGA.text: Great decor, great service, and great food! Pretty quiet at lunch, but packed for dinner. Awesome bar downstairs. The food is so interesting and different, and there were so many vegetarian options. Also, so many interesting combinations of food. I had 3 small tapas. The pea & mint empanadas were perfect, the chili quesadilla was great, and the plantain tacos were delicious. All the food was fresh, hot, had seasonal ingredients, and was served well. The service was quick and the atmosphere was so much fun. Definitely going again.

F20f8P7cBGXUyv9WOLj3xg.text: My friend and I took the selection that the waitress recommended, fairly reasonable price. The hot chocolate was nice with a touch of chili. Mojito was full of ice and that shocked me, a rip off I have to say! Having said that the food was better than I expected especially the sweet potato taquitos.

pKoVPDboGkdY1wTReOk9AA.text: Really good Mexican food! I love the chandeliers and I quite liked the whole experience.

zd3-ovI1kAUbXpIouXm18A.text: Had a brilliant night here with a group of girlfriends - the food is great and the prices are reasonable. The prosecco did seem very expensive but apart from that it was great. Good bar downstairs, cool toilets and quick servive. Would recommend!

8rDjrETMXcyXQHJRC08W3g.text: I've decided that I shall dedicate all my yelp reviews to mexican food!!!  Wahaca has pretty decent mexican food. And lord knows how I likes me some decent mexican food.In terms of ingredients, prices, and to some extent, ambiance - I'd probably fancy Wahaca as the Wagama of mexican food.I love Wagama. But I only write reviews for pseudo-mexican food joints. So.....So here's what's good about Whaca:- THE HABANERO sauce is THE MUTHA F-ING BIGGIDY-BIZ-OMB!!! **erm** sorry.....  But seriously, I love it so much that I inevitably scold the inside of my mouth every time I attempt to drink it. I can't help myself... It's. so. damn. good.- The CHAIRS downs stairs are pretty FUN. With 2 swinging chairs and 1 roly-poly chair. Butt no one really knows how to capitalize on the fun-potential the roly-poly chair might actually have to offer... - good guac (though pricey)- good ingredients (i'm of the opinion you can't mess up mexican food much with good ingredients)- Very very efficient bathroom (toilet) layout - 3.5 lady toilet options to ~2.5 mens toilet options & 1 overlap of facility w/ universal wash area... BRILLIANT.- vibrant environment  / cool takeaway items - a matchbook filled w/ Serrano Chili seeds so that you can grow your own chili plantation!Here's what sucks about Whaca:- Not enough FUN CHAIRS downstairs... - Usually a long wait (especially Friday evenings) but you can't fault them for that, right? I just did.- The chips. The chips cost £... see Chipotle review.- Not a single mexican person in site. a few Spaniards though (not the same..)- Foosball tables are NOT LEVELI'd probably give Wahaca 4.5 stars if that was even possible on yelp. But it's not. And that's okay, because only 1 out 3 of the serrano chili seeds actually worked so far... And, I'm not even sure it's actually a serrano chili plant after all... So 4 stars. 4 stars sharp.

KTB36w83I0C8AikCGsGxjA.text: We went here on the day after their opening in the very early evening and we weren't disappointed! This place offers Mexican street-style food in tapas form. We started off with the guacamole and chips which was so good I had to order more! We matched this with some of their delicious tequila and a margarita. There was a little too much salt on the margarita glass for my liking, but that's just me. The service was incredibly attentive, the staff was enthusiastic about the food, they keep checking up on us and kept an eye on our drinks which was most welcome. For the tapas I would highly recommend the Pork tortilla and the Chorizo Frijoles. They are a taste sensation. We followed their recommendation of ordering 3 tapas each but really struglled to finish them. They are surprisingly filling. The atmosphere was getting really buzzy by the time we left and I am sure it will continue to do so at lunch and dinner times being based in Soho. If I still worked in Soho I would be here every lunchtime for the Frijoles, Guacamole and Chips.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

Vl2uxYFh19_sti_im-9dLA.text: Sure it's not authentic, but it sure is tasty.  This is a tapas type Mexican restaurant.  It's great, because it allows you to order a number of items to sample the great menu.  I ended up ordering three items, but was stuffed after two.  The portions were pretty large to say the least.  The prices were decent, especially considering it is located in one of the most expensive areas of London.  Service was friendly and quick and we did not encounter a wait.  I hope they bring one of these to the US!

1lufyorU6Q065d7wLJ6bhg.text: Fresh beautiful food.  The pork tacos, steak tacos , and Caesar tostada were all excellent.  In a really competitive area the food better be good but as usual what sets apart a great place is the people.  We brought our two girls and the staff could not have been more accommodating -even dancing along to the music with them.  Totally recommend.

WqPdChvppbn1ZUeUDp_Iqg.text: I've been in search of a GREAT Mexican spot in London, and I think I found it. The atmosphere is fun, service friendly and the food is flavorful, fresh and light. I'm not a fan of the heavy, greasy, cheesy mess, where you're not quite sure were the chicken starts and the beans end, this is not the case at Wahaca. I shared the pulled pork tacos, black bean tostadas and poached chicken enchiladas with a friend, and we loved it ALL. The guacamole & tortilla chips were also fabulous! The portions aren't massive, but it allows you to order a few tacos/entrees/sides and share.The margaritas were tasty, but a bit on the icy side. Will definitely return!

kqJHhiDFo9hZF0pbjswsdQ.text: So this was a VIQ prize visit to Wahaca to sample their summer menu and we had a booked table! A booked table at Wahaca  yes you did hear me right.that is a serious prize on its own. This place is busy for good reasonyou can't book (just rubbing it in!) so arrive an hour earlier than you want to eat  grab a buzzer to let you know when your table will be ready and head downstairs to the tequila bar to grab some cocktails.the time will soon pass by.Great buzzy atmosphere, clean and cool interior and really great staff. Friendly and welcoming which is not easy to consistently deliver to queuing diners who want to be eating now. (See photo below) Great guacamole and tortilla chips  you can also choose pork scratchings. We ordered El Tesoro tequila and sangritta (a kind of non-alcoholic Bloody Mary with orange, grenadine, spice & tomato  seriously good) to accompany it.We then moved on to a series of tapas stlye taster dishes some of which we ordered ourselves and others came as our samplewe had:Squid and ChipotleMSC ceviche tostadaSummery new potato taquitoChicken tinga tacosBroadbean and feta quesadillaPork pibil tacosGrilled cornvarious beers and tequilas (See photo below) MSC ceviche tostada Shrimp and scallops with habanero chilli, lime, cucumber and mint on tortilla (See photo below) Chicken tinga tacos Chicken in a smoky tomato sauce topped with crema and extra-hot chipotle adobo (See photo below) Pork pibil tacos Slow cooked pork in a Yucatecan marinade (cumin, oregano and spices)  (See photo below) Classic Chelada Corona Extra For 50p extra you can have your beers served with salted glass rim, ice and freshly squeezed lime. Food arrives very quickly, in no particular order. Enjoyed it all  the pick was the pork pibil tacos.They do offer traditional main courses but this is a place to have fun, to experiment. to share and the street food menu is perfect for this. They offer a fixed selection of plates for 2 people to share for £19.95 which would be good place to start if you don't know the menu. Perfect for birthday outings and group bookings with friends where you cam order lots of dishes from across the menu. Its a fairly young crowd on a Saturday night (unless that's just showing my age) and it will be busy. Will be back where no doubt it will earn the extra star once we experience it without a booking and free sample menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Wahaca Wardour Street store front
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Classic Chelada Corona Extra
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork pibil

k1EpNBkrcqr6OFOeLqgppg.text: Great atmosphere. Lousy service. This Wahaca is set in an unusual setting: storage containers. It works, too. Very unique, really nice. And, for a Friday night, our food came surprisingly quick...when we finally got our server. It took him 10 min just to greet us and another 15 to come back to us for an order. Not once did he check on us to see how we were and when we were done we literally had to wave him down to get our bill. Unacceptable no matter what the night; but the kicker, it wasn't even busy. As far as I could tell he had no more than five tables. Plus, now (at least this) Wahaca is saying food may arrive at different times. They're pulling the old Wagamama chestnut of not knowing how to time cooking food. This is nothing more than laziness on the part of the kitchen. It's why I stopped going to Wagamama and why I'll stop going here if this is the new trend. For atmosphere and location it's a 4.5. For service it's a 0 - and the latter is always more important than the former!

bxmYKUITdw2jrLbcF9kALg.text: I really like this place, and I would go back again.To join the broken record bandwagon, yes, Mexican food is pretty sparse in London so that gives this place a star.  Also, it's yummy Mexican food, and they have a fair amount of vegetarian options.  I've been twice and what I've had are:  - sweet potato taquitos:  GET THESE.  So delicious with crumbled cheese on top oh god, my mouth is watering just remembering.  They are about a medium+ level of  spicy though, which some of my [weaker] friends were put off by.- bean and cheese quesadilla:  good for those wary of spice, and still scrumptious- sweet potato side:  yes, okay, I like sweet potatoes.  Moving on.  These are good too though.  Big chunky cubes, easy on the marinade, and with a kick.- guacamole & tortilla chips:  fresh sharing starter- chocolate tres leche cake:  this was also a big hit.  Dense chocolately goodness slowly drowning in the melting peanut butter ice cream.  *weeps*Other things to note is the atmosphere seems to be half what you pay for.  It's packed and bustling which I don't mind because that's city life at its best.  The decor is super nice with glass windows and walls and the downstairs tequila bar is crowded in a good way as well--but is also where you will inevitably be waiting for eternity for your table.  Both times I've been here have been for dinner, and the wait has been over 45 minutes.  Which is fine if you're with good friends, but frustrating if you're starving.Still, I like it and want to go again.

J06txEYy8dIKL8W_pFGNUg.text: I will start my review by saying that I am of Mexican heritage.  Having grown up eating this food, I am throwing in my 2 cents.Having moved to England a few months ago, I had been really eager to try Mexican food here from a chef who knows what the food and culture is all about.  I'd seen Thomasina Miers show on TV, cooking with Mexican men and women in their homes and restaurants in Mexico.  She knows the ingredients well and can pronounce them like a native Mexican.  Her enthusiasm for the culture and cuisine is evident .So, the restaurant.  It's not "authentic" per se, but more like an introduction to Mexican food for those uninitiated.  There are nods to authentic flavors, but they have been modified a bit for England(which is understandable).The pork tacos I ordered were flavorful and the meat was tender.  However, they were sopping wet, with at least a tablespoon of liquid dripping off each one.  Considering how small tacos are, this was an issue.  If I were having a stew this would have been great, but I was having a taco.The chicken tostadas were tasty.  The garnishes were modern, fresh and crunchy.  However, on such a small and thin vessel, the toppings were far too high.  Am I eating a skyscraper or a tostada?  The only thing that saved the tostada from breaking into a million pieces, were my years of experience eating these.  Any wrong move and the whole thing would have collapsed or toppled over.The horchata was a disappointment.  It's one of my favorite drinks.  It lacked cinnamon and was watered down.  Think milk + water.  Literally.The churros were not good.  I've had all kinds of churros, from Mexican street vendors, restaurants, fast-food chains, and have even made them at home.  I had high hopes. They were chewy and tough(wth) and were piped way too thickly.  They were not light and crispy.  I've had better churros in England from a Spanish market vendor in Leamington Spa.The Mexican hot chocolate was made with almond milk(pretty sure).  No.  I know this is a modern take, but at least try to make up for the switch-up with spices.  It had none and honestly tasted like someone had added a packet of chocolate powder to milk.  A little confusing to say the least.  I will summarize by saying that the entrees were tasty, but the desserts and drinks were oddly bad.  Seemingly simple things, were uncharacteristically bad.  My overall opinion of Wahaca is that it is representing Mexican food pretty accurately considering the location, England.  If you are new to Mexican food, this is a great introduction.Lastly, I really hope they jazz up the decor.  Mexico is about color and joy.  The restaurant closely resembles an IKEA dining hall, but with a few more colors.  There are ways to stay modern, while integrating the culture you are representing.

BKwMUMQ4xy0aJRKV0iKUJg.text: What can I say about Wahaca? Wooho maybe. Great food, great atmosphere, great tequila, great everything, did I mention the food. The guacamole was melt in your mouth sublime. The Wahaca selection was fantastic,  3 pork pibil tacos, 3 chicken tinga tacos, which had the right amount of spice that i didn't burn my face off but got a pleasant tingle in the cheeks. They were absolutely delicious as was the quesadilla, coleslaw and the tostadas. Best of all were the margaritas and mojitos which admittedly flowed a little too freely. Highly recommendable

SJKrzlw6OkiMJX9VzGdeew.text: Food was lovely place is nice but our waitress was rude and we weren't happy with her at all!!

YwxCzD9ef6px7IuNEXnvjg.text: WA-HA-CAIs a good 'Mexican' staple for a quick dining out option.  I've spent a lot of time in the States and been to Mexico and hear the cries constantly of Mexican restaurants that it's not authentic or traditional etc. etc.  This isn't really what Wahaca is about.  They have some ingredients and ideas taken from Mexican cooking and have put their own twist and style to them.It's nothing groundbreaking but i've been several times and everyone i know likes coming here as it has a fun and relaxed atmosphere and everyone likes small plates so there's plenty to share.  Well not everyone likes this as people get very VERY precious about their food but sharing is caring folks.They have a good selection of tacos, empanadas, taquitos, quesadillas and more.  All are tasty, but not groundbreaking.  They also have larger plates and plenty of salad options.  These aren't fantastic real Mexican flavour dishes, they are good but this is a meal where 2 people can easy be full and have a couple of drinks for £30 or less so don't expect a quinceañera in your mouth.  However, if you want an option that doesn't break the bank, is tasty, fun and where you'll get to try a few new things then absolutely give Wahaca a go.  You can't book a table in advance though so every one i have been to come stocked with a bar area where you can try some standard Mexican beers and cocktails.I've been to this location a couple of times now and in terms of service the second was absolutely great, an attentive waiter who didn't come over anymore than he needed to, and when we did need him, he was over right away.  The first time however we had a near constant bombardment of asking are we SURE we don't want to order anything else as she was placing dishes on our table.  The pushiness and annoyance of being asked how everything is every few minutes each time with a full mouth got old quickly.  Other than that though don your metaphorical sombrero and get your taco on.

ePVdnOAgN-t2QXa6wdO9aw.text: My dining companions were less than impressed with Wahaca, but I thought it was tasty. The restaurant came recommended to me by a friend as well as our local makeup artist, who we took out to dinner after a long day of hard work shooting Marcus Wareing at his restaurant and some business people at our cushy hotel. This outpost is about a ten minute walk from Mayfair.There was maybe a 15 minute wait for a table, so we headed downstairs to the bar. The space has a loungey feel with funky hanging wicker chairs and brightly colored furniture. It reminded me of SEA in New York. I didn't want to get my tequila on with such an empty stomach, but I was advised that the bartenders made a stiffer margarita than those working upstairs and serving the diners. I don't believe any kinds of chips come gratis, so we ordered chips and salsa and chips and beans. For the main event, you can mix and match a variety of tapas options, or get a larger main entree. I had a steak taco salad with pumpkin seeds, which I greatly enjoyed. I was fine with my margarita as well.They have churros on the menu for dessert(!!), but I was sadly too full to partake. I did grab a bunch of "matchbooks," which are actually chili seeds. Fun! (Was I supposed to declare those in customs? Woops)If you're in London and seeking decent mexican food with an urban hipster crowd(this is Soho, after all), Wahaca's not a bad bet.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. upstairs bar

OVWggKMEoWt8EwQ_G04_oQ.text: Delicious bites perfect to fill the gap between a late breakfast and an early dinner. Definitely could serve as more than a stopgap too, as the sizes of plates vary and this could be a nice place for dinner or lunch as well. Cool architecture fit within eight shipping containers fits well with the Southbank ethos. The place feels like a combination pop-up and Shoreditch box park. Nice work on the chorizo quesadilla (£4.10), salsa and chips (£2.95), pork tacos - a.k.a. cochinita pibil (£3.95), and the side of jalapeños I requested :) Salsa was delicious but not spicy, and pork tacos were mouthwatering - definitely recommended. I should mention that I'm from California, so I'm a bit judgmental on Mexican, but nothing about this place raised my hackles. There's also an even more temporary taco truck parked outside with a few benches if you want to-go.

Dp9LSLtMcGfKMaS4P6nkSA.text: Brilliant food and friendly service. This is my favourite place to bring people to eat when they visit me. Everything is tasty and portion sizes are just right for me off the street food menu. Love it!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. You get chilli seeds to take home!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Taquito
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Taco

z4kA1x6IWwi4cBYZVYY8dw.text: It's exotic food adapted to a local audience, sold in a nice setting. Wahaca has nothing to do with true Oaxaca-style mexican cooking, which would be different kinds of mole, loads of black beans, chapulines on cream and excellent mezcal. I've been to Oaxaca recently and I loved the food, so to me this was a bit of a dissapointment, as I expected something different. The food was ok, especially the meaty tacos and tostadas where nice, we had a seasonal special which was spicy beef - this was clearly my favourite. Taquitos and quesadillas were not memorable, neither was the guacamole. But hey - Mexico is far away, I get it.If anybody reading this knows a truly traditional mexican place, feel free to tell me! I'd be very glad!

rjYHR0Cr1OBdBlZ-auh2TA.text: Looking for a Mexican dinner, yelp helped me to find this restaurant. We had to wait about 20 minute for a table so we went to the lower flor at the tequila bar to have a margarita that was good. The room is nice with some table and little poof chairs. Talking about the dinner, the service was good even if the waiter did not understand we ordered 2 coronas because of the noise in the room. The place is really big and and with plenty of people is not easy to chat. We had 1 tacos, 1 tostadas and 1 burrito. The first 2 dishes are considered as steer food and served in mini sizes like appetizers 3 pieces for dish. The tacos was nice but almost cold. Very good the tostadas with black beans. The burrito was the main dish and finally of a normal size. The total mount for the dinner was about 23 £. Not expansive but not cheap also considering the quantity of the food. Maybe I will test some other Mexican restaurant next time, before consider it to come back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Tequila bar - lower flor
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Restaurant inside - ground flor
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Grilled British steak tacos an slow cooked pork with habanero burrito! Very good!!

I_GtwUuWScj7P1c3D6O0QQ.text: Standard Mexican food, not terrible but also not amazing.  Restaurant has a good vibe with room for lots of larger groups.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

-EsBk1X2jzHV3XkGCMMFfQ.text: YES!I went here twice in two days. First day I got the Wahaca sharing platter - the star was the pork pibil tacos. Good amount of spice to it. The second day I got the duck taquitos (they were a special that day),  pork pibil again and frijoles. This was the first time I had frijoles and they were delicious! They were topped with crema and crumbly cheese. The staff were friendly. I like how the food comes at different times and it is fun to share with your friends. The restaurant has a little magazine that keeps you updated-  they change the menu a good bit. Fish is sustainable and they try and recycle all the food waste. They seem to support small producers or use local equivalents of Mexican ingredients. I'm a fan. I believe there is an app so you can pay easily and quickly split the bill with your friends. It's a good place for groups.Tip:You get free churros if it is your birthday.

oSY3h5hmMwmiMuGHWWTS3A.text: Pretty yum, but this felt a bit cantina to me and I don't know if I liked it.  There are a fair few of these Wahacas dotted around London now and I could't help but feel it had lost a bit of its authenticity to how orchestrated and big the place was. The wine was served in thick glass tumblers which made me feel like I was drinking sour cordial and not a soft-bodied rosé from Spain.  Did not like this.The plantain tacos I had were yum, but it wasn't a lot of food for what we paid. Good spot if you like your food fast and in dainty portions. **Although, we went here because they promised gluten-free options and they delivered strongly on this, so some credit on that is due.

HCa3FJ1Tw2EtJNUigYqzZg.text: The first time was a simple burritos take-away and boy, were those burritos amazing!??! So much so that my hubby felt we need to eat their amazing burritos one more time before we leave London. So we found outselves in the restaurant and also ordered their Guacamole dip with Nachos. I don't fancy nachos back home as I always found the dips just so-so. I tried theirs and I was hooked! Hook, line and sinker! If my stomach could, I'd ordered another serving just for ME! It's honestly that good to me. Now I can only dream of it...

dEMtVmy9qrluwXUlBP8jQQ.text: We were visiting the UK and our friends in Surrey told us we should try Wahaca when in London. While down at the London Eye we visited Wahaca.The place has a good Mexican feel. Brightly colored ocean shipping containers joined together, wooden booths, simple lights add to the urban cantina vibe. The place reminded us of Jose Garce's Distrito restaurant here in Philadelphia. We were there on a warm summer day and sat in the semi-open air seating section. The menu was written on wooden tablets.We had a mixture of tacos and burritos. Everything was very fresh and the food came out quickly.Wahaca is modern Mexican food and the all the flavors were well developed. We had dessert also and that was pretty darn good also, The prices were  reasonable for London also. We don't really drink but there were quite a few people at Wahaca for the bar and margaritas and such.Definitely worth a visit if your down at the London Eye. BTB, the London Eye was FANTASTIC.

lJl81kMb3ld33JAYfbmRKg.text: So great.  Food is top quality.  It's fusion Mexican and is not like the Mexican food in Chicago.  It had a healthy modern influence on traditional dishes.  The burrito was top notch!

PisS_bM4uH8-gfVsQeX94A.text: Tried about six dishes and they were all spectacular. On a busy night the service was speedy. Cocktails definitely worth trying.

jAklFi_twOQy4JKLh7IGdQ.text: There's just something about this place that I really like. The staff are always friendly and helpful. Each of the locations around London are quite unique, especially the one by Southbank created from storage containers. It's a must visit when the weather is nice however be prepared to queue as it's quite popular.Solo or holding court for a large table this tapas/street food style menu has something for everyone. Chorizo & potato quesadillas and the sweet potato & feta taquitos are among my favorite dishes. Alas there are many more and margaritas, never forget the margarita to wash it all down.Wahaca is simple, clean, affordable and tasty which makes me come back again and again. One last thing to note is FlyPay... LOVE IT. Seriously I'm not sure why every restaurant isn't onto this feature. Scan your table's QR code using a smartphone and bam there's your bill and you can pay right from your mobile device. I'm telling you, it's awesome y'all and it's this American Southerner in London's top hit for south of the border flavors abroad.

fad15l37H1tPVUlEJvz2UQ.text: Never tasted tequila like this. Sipping instead of shoting. So good. The plantain tacos is a must. Sweet and spicy at the same time. But above all else order the Horchata!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Horchata.

woNUaVbkj2rT7tVE1jODBg.text: Coming from California, I think we are pretty spoiled when it comes to great Mexican food. I would say this tastes more like fancy cal-fresh-mex but that isn't a bad thing. We tried the sampler and everything was really good! Everything was very fresh and flavorful. The vegetable tacos were surprisingly good as well!Wahaca selectionA selection of our favourite plates for 2 people to share £19.95*3 pork pibil tacos3 winter vegetable tacos1 large huitlacoche quesadilla2 black bean tostadas2 chicken taquitos with green rice and black beansFood came out very quickly and service was friendly.Whenever we have some mexican food cravings, we will for sure come to Wahaca.

iRuC4_MdhXfQFY87FLYDhg.text: When I first moved to England I probably would have compared Wahaca's offerings to how they do it in Southern California and Arizona, where fresh, street style Mexican featuring organic/local ingredients served up in a trendy setting and alongside fine tequilas has been pretty much mastered. But where does that get us? We're not in SoCal, we're in London, where Wahaca is a fresh concept that is obviously resonating in the taste buds of the British masses. This place is packed and with a line out the door nearly every weekend night. The service is good, the food is really good, and the décor and ambience captures that casual Gulf of Mexico vibe with an edgy L.A. Dia de Los Muertos kick. I really enjoyed the refried beans and chips app, made with black beans and smothered in delicious cheese. The guacamole wasn't the best I've had, but fresh and with just the right amount of lime. The chips could definitely be better - but many Mexican places overlook this staple, and it's a shame. Just because you load it with fixins doesn't mean it shouldn't have a crisp freshness and flavor of its own. I recently had the three street tacos small plate order which, along with the beans and guac apps, was plenty for me (the server really tried to talk me into getting another small plate but I'm glad I didn't). I've also had the cochinita pibil burrito which left me a little unimpressed but not regretful. Overall it's a great menu with everything from quesadillas to tostadas to tacos to flautas and burritos.My one major gripe is with the serving style. I hate that the plates arrive at the table "as they are ready". Sure, this is common in beach-front food shacks which are a one-man show, but this is a well-oiled popular restaurant with diners who were taught that it's rude to start eating until everyone has their food. I can't stand eating cold food and can't stand poor manners. It's a no-win situation for me.BTW, "Wahaca" is the phonetic pronunciation of the city of Oaxaca, Mexico. When my husband kept talking it up, I was really impressed that the restaurateur took such a difficult name and slapped it on a new dining concept. When we finally went and I saw the sign, I smiled. Gotta ease 'em, in, I guess.

P50T1oAAjpZLMQIZPE9fAQ.text: Great quality Mexican fast food.This site is also really fun and the cocktails are great.I would treat it like tapas and order loads of things to share. The little plates are perfect for two people sharing.

i5pf83-S9xFSUhoUT4LSOg.text: LOVE Wahaca! The perfect social spot for big groups or small groups, the service is always so, so quick and you never have to wait long for a table.The food is always delicious and there is just enough to fill you up, but you never feel like you have spent too much money. I love the steak meals and the sweet potato fries.The best Mexican in London for sure!

fKMlBigY1imYLBQIv1XfJw.text: Amazing place..Their guacamole is awesome! And all the service is perfect.. They always try to help you with the orders if you have some problems.Try also the plantain taco!

iWf3MPH2BN6VTiPsq34EOw.text: I have been living London for all but 2 months and have struggled to find any Mexican food. Coming from Southern California I knew it would be a tough task to find anything decent. Luckily we found this little gem. The food here is outstanding although it is slightly different from the traditional Mexican food I am used to. I had the pork burrito and the chorizo and potato quesadilla and both were excellent. I understand that this location is not permanent but hopefully not.

qS-fvyfEpeE5L4NSTKeyyA.text: Really good. Was there last weekend with friends. Great buzz about the place. The only downside was we had to wait nearly an hour and a half to get a table. We passed the time having some cocktails. It was a Saturday night by the way! If you're going on a weekend night go knowing you're going to wait and have a few drinks to pass the time. Staff were good. Drinks and food were good.

pW9J8gZOE-_Qfq18jPqGag.text: I went there at lunch time last month and I ordered 3 dishes from the Street Food Menu` which were Cactus Taco, MSC Ceviche and Chipotle Chicken. I am a virgin when it comes to Mexican food. I have never been inspired by the American chain in the past but now it has all changed and I thought I will give it a try. Nice decor and cool toilets. I didn't t realize that they would bring all the dishes at the same time as I thought the warm one might get cold but it didn't. I started off with the prawn one. It was quite delicious but I soon realized that what was delicious was the marinate not the prawns, completely tasteless and watery. You know when you put frozen prawn in water they will eventually defrost but you need to squeeze them a little bit otherwise you are left with what I experienced. It is all very well that the fish is environmentally sustainable but what about the flavour? The next one, the cactus taco was not too bad with good texture but I was not very impressed. Lots of chilli sauce that I had to wipe off with a napkin that I nicked from next table because my one was already full of sauce. The Chipotle Chicken was more to my taste with a lot of cheese which at times could be overpowering. Fortunately I started with the least flavoursome dish first increasing to more interesting flavours later. Had it been the other way round I would not considering returning. I also had a Citrus Fizz - very pleasant. Overall I think it was a good experience and I want to go back to try different dishes. One last thing, when they give you the bill, they also give you something that for a moment without my glasses resembled a book of matches and I thought that it was a bit weird, why would they give you matches? Do they want to encourage you to smoke? Soon after I realised that they were chilli seeds to be planted. That made me smile, I thought it was cute.

cuP9xO7b8eh7sPEqX3WS0Q.text: Being from SoCal where authentic Mexican restaurants are only a few miles away, I was surprised to find how good this place was.  I mean, let's be clear.  Of course, this isn't the best OR authentic Mexican restaurant but we have to take into consideration that we are in fact, on the other side of the pond here.  So with that in mind, I found Wahaca delicious and satisfying.  My girlfriends and I came here for a birthday and I must say.. the wait was horrendous.  There were about 20 of us and we waited close to 2 hours EVEN WITH A RESERVATION.  We were very agitated to say the least but for some reason we decided to stick it through and just wait patiently.  A few of us ordered a couple of drinks and they were so delicious!  The food was fresh and colorful and equally appetizing.  The portions were generous and most importantly, affordable! Overall it was a great time minus the hours spent waiting.

VjjC7jb_iSv22BwzTXEoYg.text: Good food and service but spicyness there is a KILLER.

2fAGgQFoAw_xiVDcLp5tcA.text: this last time i was in wahaca it wasn't as nice as the ones before... I got there at rush hour at dinner time and I realized that you can't book a table, anyway I waited in the funky bar downstairs and had loads of fun with the "futbolito" table while waiting and enjoying a drink... the staff is everywhere but nowhere at the same... the food was good but it came cold.. my "must have" michelada beer was very spicy and served by an angry Argentinian bartender who was very rude serving at the downstairs bar and, finally when ordering food they didn't have the tamales nor the flan de la casa available... Usually it's a great place to eat in I'm a big fan of it, but sadly it's just when they have time for you and there's more staff than clients... To me this experience kind of showed me that it's becoming a cheap chain of mexican food... the newsletter is the same one of over a year ago and the menu is still in winter time... It was really disappointing.

QLnLaTRA9fEPLsGSx2mVYQ.text: If you crave fresh Mexican food, Wahaca does the trick. It isn't a lot of food, but the menu is diverse and the food is fresh. Usually a very long wait to get a table, though.

v1ByXkW_KEiAuMtLXuUxBg.text: Long wait unless you arrive early - be prepared to wait for at least 1 hr on a Saturday evening.  However, food is good and consistent (the small dishes are generally better than mains - try the fish tacos and mole chicken), margaritas very yummy, prices reasonable and service is good.  Great for a casual meal.

RS_ko3YuqwcEywQeQjhcuw.text: Decent food. Nothing special. Pork rinds instead of nachos were interesting.

a1ft2NC6hiTB3gk_Nni_Fw.text: Nice Mexican for London. Worth a visit for sure! The tapas choice is nice because u can taste different dishes. Their Margarita's are pretty good too. Staff are really friendly and helpful. Recommend!

ztrJ6z5vkOxZ1rEowTurEQ.text: Wahaca is amazing for authentic Mexican. After spending a few weeks in Mexico I realised the tex mex you generally he in places like TGI Fridays is not the same as genuine Mexican flood. Wahaca is one of my favourite restaurants in London. Pork tacos, black bean tostadas, guacamole and chorizo quesadillas are pretty hard to beat!

SrJ6ON15Owv5rOx_ce3-Zw.text: I had an absolutely amazing dinner here with a friend. The Huaracha was my favorite dish by far, but everything I tasted was delicious. And the wine pours were extremely generous by any standards, and certainly reasonable by London's. I highly recommend it, and if you can get there early, you'll have no trouble getting a table. It gets very busy at about seven o'clock, but if you're in by six, you'll have a fabulous dinner without any wait. Service is excellent as well.

7mJV0RwFizKXl4Umn9XqVg.text: I loved it! Especially the idea of small portions where you can try many of your Mexican favorites at the same time. This is a gourmet Mexican restaurant. The atmosphere is very lively, colors and decoration are super bright. The service was very good and the best of all everything we tried tasted very delicious. The different salsa sauces and the presentation of the food, absolutely wonderful. I wish a place like this existed in Copenhagen (where I live currently).

UFzEabNRly_VHJU0XJgDlA.text: I went a couple of Weeks ago,  the food was excellent great value for money...........

qea-OJLgW1_SZNdLZ4O9DQ.text: I went here last night with some friends, I've been MANY times before but I really can't seem to get enough. I absolutely LOVE the food. We did order WAY too much, as usual. Normally I get two choices from the street food section of the menu but last night I got caught up in all the ordering and went for three, but it's really too much and then there is no room for Churros... which is a tragedy in itself. If you've not been GO!

RcYGbu4EzZPsSKDM8xCJ8g.text: Ahh, Wahaca how I love thee. The only problem with this place is its popularity. It's always sooo busy, and as they don't take bookings you usually find yourself in the downstairs bar drinking way too many tequilas whist you wait for a table.The food is always fab though (not just because you've had a few margaritas), and fantastic value for money. Ask for dulce de leche with the churros instead of chocolate sauce and you'll be in heaven.

o4DWUGvXw7kGQKqn43klrA.text: I've been here a few times. It has some interesting vegetarian options, I especially like their vegetarian main course salad, and the fact that they experiment with interesting combinations, such as lancashire cheese and black bean. They put the same degree of creativity into their vegetarian options as the rest of the menu which is really nice. They also have a really interesting drinks menu  various types of tequila are perhaps to be expected but they also have some Mexican non-alcoholic drinks that are interesting and a bit different to what you would normally get at a Mexican restaurant.They lose points for me for other things though: atmosphere  the place is incredibly noisy and not all that comfortable); and the fact that they bring the food to you at random intervals, which they claim is about the authentic street food experience (um, wouldn't that involve an actual street?) but seems to me to be more about laziness about co-ordinating things in the kitchen, I love tapas/mezze style eating but not when it's forced on me and I don't get any choice about what dish comes when.

eRKDaQQyswQO2KA4lew57w.text: This place was great! I have lived in southern california and used to eat Mexican weekly before I went to Edinburgh for school. This was a great experience of freshly and creatively done Mexican. There was too many delicious items so I went with three things from the "street food" section - all delicious. My only complaint is avocado quality. BUT quality avocados aren't the easiest to find in the UK.

mP9b4xdEQQqCzTO6um6Aqw.text: Buena comida cada vez que tienen la mejor salsa criolla pimienta!

wiNh4JeEoeqmBr6tT4TxgA.text: My first experience of a tapas style meal. Honestly a fantastic place with great atmosphere and service! Best to go with a large group as you can order lots of small dishes, it can get very pricey with just two of you!! X

uLgiTdXNWdm_uRi4LL3ekw.text: The perfect place for meeting up for a quick meal in the West End. I had seen this new outpost of the Wahaca chain pre-opening and vowed to come back as it looked so colourful - I'm glad I did! OK, it was the Tuesday before Christmas, but the entire place was so packed we barely managed to get a table for two in front of the open kitchen. Although there were people waiting to be seated, they seemed to be taken care of quickly and I have to say that there was a really buzzing and convivial atmosphere!When my friend (finally) arrived we shared a bottle of their house red and decided on a few tapas-type plates to share.First was slow cooked pork bilpil tacos, chorizo and potato quesadillas and street food special - Queso Fundido with (garlicy mushrooms in a cheesy taco ) All these street food dishes are betweem £3.95 and £5.00 which is very cheap for the portions, but there are also larger meals like burritos, enchilladas and grilled meats etc for higher prices.I would definitely go back here - there is a good atmosphere, service was friendly and surprisingly, our waiter didn't rush us out despite the high turnover of tables.

s7AV2vV-iy1Ac0s6HK5Vxg.text: I must sheepishly admit that this is a bit of a belated review for a wonderful meal at the Wahaca in Soho (for the Qype event for Thomasina Miers' new BBC show, Mexican Food Made Simple), but better later than never.So I have a soft spot for Mexican food  and as a girl from Los Angeles, born and raised, I have had my fair share of Mexican food  and Wahaca did not disappoint. Wahaca is marketed as a genuine Mexican street food experience  and the evening duly met that expectation.Although the Qype event was only held in the basement/bar area of the restaurant (which we consequently spent most time in), the main upstairs dining area grew to be quite convivial and rather bustling, especially for an unassuming Tuesday night.We were continually plied with fantastically fresh salsa and guacamole and given full access to the open bar (hellooo endless mojitos!) which was staffed by terrifically accommodating bartenders  so what's not to love?All in all, the infallible plus one and I left the restaurant completely satisfied and pleased with our meal.

EdqpJAPfrlYpYx0kwXVYjA.text: Friday night was an hour and half wait! Get ready to go downstairs and play some table football (foosball)! The wait for was an hour downstairs anyway so you're in a holding pen and queuing all at once. It's popular, what can I say. So, once seated you're full of tequila and and margaritas and ready to inhale anything that comes your way. The esquites were delicious (like elotes but in a bowl). Mmm. The food came quickly and the service was attentive. Prices overall are great for the quality of the dishes. Can't wait to visit again! just earlier!

VGOUmfb2VvUl8XsXSUGUeQ.text: I visited Wahaca on invitation via Qype and I must say that it was spectacular. the evening went well and I was not disappointed. I would gladly recommend all my friends to go there as the food was great and the atmosphere wonderful.Thanks Qype

F9XAHnfTamOLHZ9L6mC1_Q.text: I definitely liked Wahaca, no matter what my Mexican friends say about it not being very authentic. The staff were ultra friendly, the restaurant had a lively atmosphere, with great decor, the food was all very different. Portions were confusing however. If anything, they could do with a smaller, more refined menu. But taste-wise our sharing dishes for 2 were delicious! And I loved the touch of gifting each patron with some chilli seeds packed into what looked like a match-box at the end. A very unique touch. Wahaca is definitely worth a trip, but not with one of those friends who likes to bang on about 'authentic' in the context of food.

l3AajC316A_EhEMuEImtbA.text: I like the concept of this kind of mexican restaurant. The decoration of the restaurant is amazing. I tried cochinita pibil, and it was like in mexico. I really recommend this place.

qO2l_v8Xm890_gD1-Qhylg.text: Being a Texan, I'm a tough customer when it comes to Mexican food of any kind.  Having been to the Texas Embassy on previous London trips (purely for novelty purposes), my expectations for London Mexican food was, let's just say, really low.  Wahaca, though, didn't disappoint!When we went, it was a Friday night, I was with a big group of hungry and thirsty Royal Opera performers.  It was really busy when we got there, so we retreated downstairs to the bar.  They offered a few Mexican beer selections and a very nice selection of tequilas.  We all opted for margaritas.  I chose Don Julio tequila and the hilarious bartenders practically made me their patron saint of tequila!  "Oh you must know your stuff!  Everybody here orders Patron!"  We got in a bit of a conversation about where I'm from and tequilas.  They were nice enough to pour me a free shot of Centenario Anejo!  We had great fun in the bar waiting on our table.  I don't even know how long we were down there (it was over an hour), but the atmosphere was very lively and typical of a trendy place in Soho.  By the time we were ready to be seated, we were drunk and happy.  Food almost seemed moot at that point!But it wouldn't be a proper review if I didn't give my semi-professional opinion on cuisine that we do very well in Texas, being our close proximity to Mexico.  I had to try their tacos.  I ordered the pork and shredded beef tacos, with a chorizo and potato quesadilla.  They were quite good!  I was almost shocked at how good they were compared to authentic Mexican fare back in the states!  The shredded beef was decent, but the specialty pork tacos were amazing.  Add a splash of habanero hot sauce on the table and it becomes something very familiar to me back home.  We call it 'al pastor' and it delivers.  They come served on little corn tortillas, 3 to an order.  I had the 2 plates of tacos and it was filling.  I don't think 1 order of tacos would suffice someone getting full.  The quesadilla was very forgettable.  It was mushy and didn't have a whole lot of flavor to what I'm used to.Overall, this is a fun, hip place in Soho that's probably about as close as it gets to real Mexican food in London.  I highly recommend it, being a self-proclaimed Mexican food expert.  The price for the meal is very reasonable in an expensive London food scene.  I believe our bill was only 50 quid for the 4 of us, including drinks.

iSu92RQekPQ_VxZonVUNKg.text: Love this place!The staff are always cheerful, food is served quickly and tastes amazing! Always the place friends and I go to last minute. You usually have to wait to be seated (during busy times, obviously) but there is a bar downstairs, so the time passes quickly!Would definitely recommend if you're a Mexican foodie!

Lusz-3Y-rlyvIOIBkP8o4A.text: We came to Wahaca expecting a decent attempt at Mexican food in London, but they absolutely exceeded our expectations. Each location seems to produce the same quality of food, which is a huge nod to the chefs. We went to the Southbank location last night and the Soho location tonight. We ordered some of the same items at both locations and the dishes were so similar in flavor, I forgot we were at a different restaurant. The Vampiro juice is really refreshing, despite its dark color. The Classic Margarita is excellent and leaves you wanting anything round. The Twisted Mojito DF is good, but I prefer mojitos with rum instead of tequila as they use here. The standout items were the Pork Pibil Tacos; the Plantain Tacos; the Tender, Marinated Chicken Taquitos; the Broccoli with Green Goddess dressing; and the Sweet Potato side. The pork tacos are so amazing I swear you could drink the juice by itself. The chipotle sauce used on the taquitos is a perfect blend of smoky and sweet, with a hint of spice. The potatoes are perfectly cooked and seasoned, I just wish you got more with your order. Overall, I love this place. I just wish we had it in the U.S.

ACFxobakOzDpjTOwx_HWYA.text: Had dinner here last night with 3 friends after our plans to try Bone Daddies went down the drain when we saw the queue outside. The place is really big, it's got a nice atmosphere and we were seated immediately despite it being really busy (especially for a Tuesday night). I love Mexican food and I tried more many Mexican restaurants than any other type so I was really excited to try out the food here. But alas, I wasn't really blown away. We ordered some quesadillas to share and as a main I ordered the 'British steak, the Mexican way', which came served with green rice. It wasn't disgusting, but I've had better steaks at the local pub. It was quite tough on the edges and chewy inside, I would have gladly added a bit of salt to give it some extra flavour but there was none on the table, and before I could call someone the steak was going cold so I ate it as it was. Bit disappointing. I've tried to save the meal by ordering some churros, which were actually super nice. Crunchy, warm, served with dark chocolate sauce, I loved them and could have probably eaten 10 more. Kudos for the very good prices (spent £17 in total for 3 courses) and for how quick they serve the food. Would like to go back to give the food another chance and maybe try the mini soft tacos they do, but for now A-OK is how I feel about Wahaca.

kyLf4zZNmW53LB2HrIVXcg.text: Wahaca is one of my favorite places in London to get a yummy dinner with friends on a budget. If you order and split the menu for two, you get a wonderful selection of the restaurant's best meals, and you leave with a bang for your buck. The atmosphere in all the joints is very cozy and friendly, so it is just an incredibly pleasant place to hang out at.Also, the famous pork pibil tacos are just phenomenal - a must try for any Mexican cuisine lover.

xwp08vsiQkYvnb7vVGj91w.text: Great authentic Mexican atmosphere! With clean restaurant and bathrooms this place has it all food and drinks included! Prices are great and staff as well! It's hard to find good service and this place does it well! It's refreshing to find a place where the staff is extra helpful and the food is just as amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

Z4kVEdig0I9puQqkT8APjg.text: Average Mexican food overall, but better than other Mexican food I've tried in London. They have a nice selection of stereotypical Mexican food, such as burritos, tacos, and quesadillas. I ordered the chicken quesadilla (4 quid) from the 'street food' section, which came with two slices of cheesy, spicy shredded chicken goodness. A few other friends ordered burritos (7 quid) from the 'bigger food' section, which were pretty large and came with some tortilla crisps on the side. We had the guac as an appetizer, and it was pretty standard fare.Tl;dr - standard Mexican fare in London.

fLWN31j6GIfbI1ZmWZyiFw.text: An awesome find while walking around London! A desperate need when away from California.

Tyd7kVnpNzdMSx77yt7R4A.text: Though this wasn't what we would call Tex-Mex or legit Tacos, the food was edible and tasty. The service was OK and they now have an app where you can pay through the app then leave. I am not sure I like that bit. I was disappointed in that the salsa was not very good and watery. The tacos were on the bit experimental side but tasty nonetheless. There could have been more tortilla chips with the side order of salsa as they  were good. Like my title of this review say, it was a good solid choice but not memorable

nGGb2tggBuyRODzgyHpBMw.text: this is a young and trendy place with amazing authentic food, and absolutely readonable prizes!  it gets a little crowded during lunch time, but that's to be expected. we went there to munch on burritos and were nothing but satisfied!

onIa94cdpqb5A54th4sgAQ.text: I originally visited this restaurant during the first momths it opened in 2011. Back then, I was very excited for a new Mexican flair to pop up near Covent Garden. The interior design created a certain ambiance and the food in their first year was generous and injected with flavor. Flash forward years later,  I was totally turned off by the lousy service and stingy portions of food they were serving. It was if my beloved steak burrito shrunk.  Well, at least there's some crusty, plain tortilla chips to go along with that day old salsa. Wahaca just lost its mojo!

xSYDqTzHEsdrcS65HBqj0A.text: Excellente.  Their spin on Mexican food works very well.  We ordered the Wahaca Selection (a variety of tapas of tacos, taquitos, quesadilla and slaw).  My wife and son order taquitos and steak burrito.Everything was terrific.  Some dishes really surprised me, especially the potato taquitos and the broad bean quesadilla were uniquely good.  The reason why I say that is because I would have never thought to make these dishes this manner.My wife loved her beef burrito and my really enjoyed his chicken taquitos.The churro with chocolate was good.  And our caramel, salted ice cream was (as my daughter said) confusingly good. Overall, this was a great eating experience.  The quality of the food was excellent and I highly recommend it.

CF78X6sM37hkTsxc6ao_Xg.text: It was a recommandation from a friend. We never heard about that restaurant before and we got surprise. The food was amazing, the service was perfect and the drinks were amazing too. Truly love the ambiance too. We are keeping this restaurant on our list for the next time we are coming in London. Thank you again!

GV6J13HVjUKt87GH6eB-ZQ.text: Oh dear...another review of mine where I am probably the odd ball in the room! I am not trendy and I don't like trendy restaurants, where you sit in a big room with many other people and you have to scream at each other if you want to have a conversation: this is what Wahaca is like to me! Further, the turn-over is really high, which always makes you feel that there's something hectic going on around you. The food: it's really just A-OK...my quesadilla was quite alright, but the Winter Salad was just not tasty at all. The guacamole on the other hand was tasty, yet the chips were somewhat stale. Thankfully, all of the food was reasonably priced and so I didn't feel that I paid too much for a mediocre dining experience......yet, and this is where they really lost the third star that I was willing to give them: on the bill it says in bold letters "SERVICE NOT INC" and then in fine print underneath "unless for parties of 5 or more, where a discretionary charge of 12.5% will be added to your bill".This is just taking advantage of the customer, who will read the bold message and might just add tip again, even though it has already been added!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The rip off with the service charge!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo & Potatoe Quesadilla

6rL1g8sk2lprE2Q5dDbEkQ.text: Solid street Mexican place that will fast claim a permanent spot in my weekly lunch line up - two big steak tacos will only set u back 5 pounds 50 pence - chips and ample guac only another 2.50 - would recommend coming here for lunch or a casual dinner to anyone in the area!

5HUGxzI1qAulh2-24ha2dA.text: This canteen style Wahaca has an excellent location on the South Bank which means it is usually incredibly crowded. We arrived early and not in a major hurry so put our names down and headed upstairs to the bar (you can put your group down even if not everybody has arrived, but you won't be seated until everyone arrives, although if by that point you're the top of the queue you will be seated next, if that makes sense...). Service at the bar is slow which is a bit annoying but the drinks are good (I recommend the hibiscus mojito over the margarita, the margarita is a very short drink and by the time you have panted your way to the bar and back you will have finished it). It's ideal at this stage to get some guac and chips as the guac is good and it will stave of hunger irritability.I've found before at Wahaca that the food comes out somewhat randomly and they tend to make mistakes e.g. bringing double the order or missing part of it and bringing it later or not at all. So keep an eye on it if you're in a group - the server made no fuss at all when we mentioned something hadn't arrived.So as for the food - our gluten free friend was delighted to find she could eat most of what was on the menu (tacos, taquitos although not quesadillas or burritos). Tacos were overall pretty good (we tried chicken, pork, steak and cactus and all went down well, the steak probs my fave) although in fact I was more of a fan of the quesadillas especially with the house sauce (the brown one). I particularly loved the sweet potato side which combined 2 of my favourite food qualities: sugar and garlic.The seating area we had was cosy and seated 6 easily, it was great for a group. Downside of the bar area is that there isn't much seating for a larger group.Would definitely recommend as long as you are not starving or in a hurry.

lEwKSmu8HsadMFllhV7nJg.text: I stumbled upon this place accidentally, and had some of the best authentic Mexican tacos I've ever had! I sat down at the "Taco Away" bar, and had the pleasure of being served by Ricardo, an outstanding cook and really nice guy. He was a joy to speak to while I enjoyed my meal. The food was amazing.. The "BLT" tacos are worth the trip out here.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. "BLAT" - perfection!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Ricardo preparing my "BLAT" taco!

Zw4BdvBnFcwUc-ufh4TQ4Q.text: Relatively speaking, Wahaca's street food stand serves up a decent burrito. It's no Freebird, but I'd go so far to say that it's at least as good as Chilango, and the ladies behind the counter can at least wrap the things appropriate (unlike the ones that work at Chipotle).Unlike your typical street food vendor, this Wahaca actually has tables and seating, which makes immediately tearing through the foil and stuffing your face full of tortilla-wrapped goodness extra convenient. There's nothing like instant gratification to satisfy the soul when your tummy's rumbling.Whilst I wouldn't recommend going massively out of your way for a lunch here, if you happen to be in the area and looking for a quick meal, this stand will set you back £6-8 for a substantial portion, and you won't be going hungry anytime before dinner!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

SjlvgMX19oeLGSy3RvVgtQ.text: Oh man... Mexican food. I'm sorry to say but Mexican food has yet to make a serious impression on me in Europe. I perceive myself a connoisseur of empanadas, tacos, tamales, and taquitos. I may be overstating my importance and knowledge of the cuisine but I do have a extreme love for it and it is one of the few foods, aside from mom's, that I have craved ever since moving here.I went to Wahaca for a Birthday Dinner for one of my coursemates on a Anthropology of Food course. I trust my peers to lead me to good restaurants though I was a bit dubious when she told me that it was going to be Mexican food. Several other American classmates and natives to South America were a bit skeptical but we arrived after several pints at the student bar. With a little extra encouragement our hesitations turned into excitement to try the foods. Wahaca does "upscale street food", as I call it. It's not street food. It's not the greasy, grubby, stuff you get from a sweaty man hovering over an steaming griddle; not entirely sanitary but saintly in taste. At Wahaca everything is plated on white plates; if it were a person it would be dressed in Sunday's best. Ultimately, through the haze of a few pints of ale and a traditional mojito, I came to the conclusion that the food was... good; not amazing, outstanding, or life changing but enough to satisfy my crave for tacos, taquitos and other various forms of Mexican street food. The price of the food is a different story. It's Soho, so I expected a pretty high price and I wasn't wrong. I spent 23 quid here and I split the bill with a friend of mine. In total it came out to about 50 between the two of us and that is very pricey for a graduate student. All things considering, this is a good restaurant. Had this restaurant been in America, I probably would have rated it 3-stars rather than 4. For me, having been spoiled with growing up so close to Mexico it's easy to find amazing Mexican food for a very cheap price, but Wahaca is hands down the best Mexican food that I have had in London SO FAR.

ZeFKqnqCmScqrbkJWEXVpw.text: Authentic latin food.  Tacos, fish, salsas..... All good.  Great service. Kids are well attended to.  Cocktails are great.  Fun for singles too

8ZWZ0F-5pkEuxbx5ejenNg.text: I love Wahaca, we arrived at 9 and were told it was a 30 minute wait. After 10 minutes we were offered a table with another couple - only downside really as an Englishman I found this a tad awkward. Our waitress was lovely and attentive if a bit rushed off her feet and the open windows really allowed a lot of air to circulate through the restaurant on a mild summers evening. The food itself was very good, I can only imagine some of the margins they have on the products though. The broccoli dish was delicious of course but quite overpriced. My favourite dish of the evening was the Sweet Potato Taquitos (we decided to be a fat and ordered it again). Oh and the cocktails were glorious as well. I would recommend the Gin Sling (our waitresses favourite). We didn't go for dessert as we had already stuffed ourselves full so I can't comment on that but I plan to in the future....Overall very good food, lovely service and a cool, relaxed atmosphere for a Saturday Summer evening on Southbank. I will definitely be returning.

by-rbikjlsxXdmfuNiWJiQ.text: Just had a wonderful Mexican meal at wahaca. We had multiple small plates on the suggestion of Ana, our server, great advice. The sweet potato and feta taqueria were amazing!

FTUT6ESmYd79U_zhvw1EPg.text: California burrito fanatic eager to try a burrito in London. I tried the British steak burrito and horchata. Every thing was just different. Very gourmet. Filling but not quite as tasty where it would drive me to come back. And I didn't know cheese was extra because the waitress didn't make it known that it would be extra. Benito's hat is cheaper and just as full filling.

ZbKET7BnSijluh0zNGqo4g.text: I think this Wahaca has the most fun and lively atmosphere of all of them, which is saying a lot. You may have to wait for a table but the downstairs bar is super fun and a great place to have a drink while you wait for your little pager to go off. Service can be kind of rude but I suppose that's pretty standard for central London.

Y-NeHudWVfjyI6PEJAeMSQ.text: This place is an experiment.Wahaca -the folks that have brought great Mexican flavours to London have decided that they want to challenge themselves and their chefs by setting up a temporary restaurant in the heart of the South Bank along the banks of the Thames. Eight shipping containers have been joined together and painted vibrant colours. This restaurant and the food truck out front serving truly authentic Mexican Street Food have shook up this little corner of London. Like a transport depot which arrived to piss off the badly costumed SpongeBob and a very short Darth Vader outside hustling tourists for pictures. Inside they have some really clever seating both in and around of the containers. Authentic Central American beers and some stunning Tequila mixed drinks were a great start. The we kicked into some a plate of amazing Carne Tacos and stupidly gorgeous guacamole with home-made tortillas. . Then a really great sharing plate of various substances. Black beans, mashed green chillies, cilantro, a stack of tortillas and finally a large pot of Cola marinaded pulled pork. Absolutely stunning. Medium priced but definitely worth the visit. Amazing view of the river while munching on great Mexican food. This is truly is a great experiment but one that will not last for long - in eighteen months from this review - it will be gone, Get your ass down here soon and enjoy it before it goes.

1YOEYZY8Df_bEcTMXUID7w.text: My husband and one year old and I had dinner here this past weekend and were very pleasantly surprised! It's not always easy finding a spot to bring the baby but this was just perfect. We were welcomed in and led to a perfect table right near the baby changing facility, which was much appreciated. Service was excellent and the food as well. We ordered the Wahaca street food combo for £19.99 and added a couple things to it. Everything was outstanding except the chicken Parmesan tostada which we found quite bland, however it was perfect for our daughter so we couldn't really complain. We'll definitely be back!

dYKUTQNjQDOa6hMwwLjZqA.text: I was traveling alone and decided to stop here for dinner what a great place!   It was a Friday night - lots of energy - totally full of people having a great time. The only downside is it's a bit loud but it's a fun space to end your week.  I had a dinner of "street food" which equates to small plates so that you can have a variety of different experiences. I enjoyed them (2 - 3 as suggested is the right amount) but I have to comment expressly on  the taquitos - specifically the sweet potato & feta taquito was an unexpected treat.  I generally stray away from anything described as deep fried but they were truly wonderful!

mTj7NdpyDEKWwM5GotIqVw.text: Okay, I have to give the restaurant some leeway because, well, London has a sparse population of Mexican chefs compared to San Diego, CA, where I'm from. But here I go...The place (food and atmosphere) can hardly be called Mexican. It's got more European flair than anything. For food, it's definitely edible and can be pleasant if you're not distracted by what it's supposed to be, but it's more like that awkward cousin of Spanish food dressed in a sombrero and some misguided gaucho trousers. When you go get Mexican food, you expect it to be dirt cheap, but this place is more like a pricey gastropub than a mom and pop shop. The decor is slick rather than homey. The wait could compare to a good Mexican eatery, however, when you get to the end of the queue, there isn't a tasty carne asada street taco waiting for you. I wouldn't avoid this place, just know that when you eat here (especially for the travelers out there), don't come expecting legit Mexican food.

IZn6gCRXjkQRdJxgJ__xZA.text: Fell in love with this place on my first London visit in 2011 and was so pleased that it still existed upon my return this year. Fantastic Mexican food!

2wkFIq8uqEHJ1yFtS8k5Gg.text: Fantastic food in street food portions. Order as much or as little as you like. Great for sharing. Staff and service is excellent. Pricing is very reasonable. Drinks and cocktails selection is also very good.

OZpX-aSxvvHEyePSexFBEA.text: Pork tacos, margs, and guac were delicious! Antonio and the staff were awesome! Glad to have this place as our first stop for food in London!

L-ASReDQ-P0AqPvQvkMOjQ.text: Short: I really recommend this place and I'd go there again.This place is nice. Really hip and modern, it's just the way I like it. There was a long wait though for the table for two, but okay, it was Saturday evening, so that's totally acceptable. We just hung around at the bar, had a couple of cocktails and tortilla chips with that awesome freshly made salsa.The food was quite decently priced and very delicious. And the waiter was total fun!If I lived in London I'd go there quite often.

wSb2cc4b_RNpFv2Dbm3xKQ.text: Good good and good atmosphere.  The waitress knew her menu and suggested some suggestions. We had the bean dip, guac, quesadillas, and taquitos. The food is good but nothing close to the Mexican food you get in California, which is understandable. Gets the craving done!The best part about this place is the atmosphere. It's loud, rowdy, and people start dancing next to their table. Overall it's a good place for younger crowd who want to party, specially at night.

N02k7U4MkHHDhRY3nUFmaA.text: If you know me, you know I'm picky about Mexican food.  Living in Southern California all my life, I've had some pretty good Mexican places to choose from thanks to the fine influence of our neighbors south-of-the-border.  When my friend suggested eating at Wahaca, I thought "Mexican food, in London?  At a restaurant that doesn't spell the region's name correctly?  Hmm... this is going to be disappointing."  Boy, was I wrong!Wahaca was packed, so we were ushered to the underground margarita bar.  Both the Wahaca and the Berry on-the-rocks margaritas were outstanding.  After some great people-watching, we found ourselves upstairs sharing the Wahaca Selection -- which is a collection of dishes designed to share.  The pork pibil tacos were outstanding, flavorful with a little spice.  The potato taquitos were also a nice touch.  The spicy habanero sauce was sweet and spicy, just like a habanero should be.  The tostadas, chicken tacos, and guacamole were also good.  They make their mojito with tequila, which is a different, but yummy touch.  The price was outstanding (especially for London).  Not quite the flavor of a taco stand in Mexico, but a nice upscale version of Mexican food, much like LA's Frida or Rosa Mexicano.  I'd come back here again, hands down.

7RkpQRZ9Xd3UhL89oQgIuQ.text: Wahaca.The misspelled maker of decent, but not fabulous, food at high prices.Here's the thing: I like Wahaca. It came out of Masterchef and it's decent and all. Not bad. Kind of spendy.But.But you get a really nice tostada de ceviche, with well-made ceviche, and they put it on so much flavourful lettuce that it's hard to taste the bloody ceviche.Much of the food is decent, and it's a decent place to go for a party or something, and they do well, but it's also rather loud and has really high turnover and it's pretty expensive.It's not quite so bad in Covent Garden, but in Soho you'l end up with the inevitable drunken Midlandsers who don't know where they are and stumble around in the toilet area. In all honesty, there are better places cheaper in London to get Latin American food. But I'm glad they're doing ell.

-nGboY36O44z0mUQMrlecw.text: Oh man. I just love it here!My obsession is Thai street food. I mean I'm totally obsessed. I love regional Isaan food best, but anything best served anywhere in Thailand on a plastic stool five inches above the ground is good with me. Thomasina Miers, who owns the Wahaca chain, also has a street food obsession, her passion is for Mexican.I've been to a Yelp event here and loved the tasters we were given, now I've been back to eat for real I can definitely say that the street food section of the menu is a solid five stars. As are the Corona Micheladas. The British steak burrito was only okay though, a bit dense, lacking in freshness and not hugely flavourful.This time we started with a portion of the Guacamole and pork scratchings, as if anything involving pork skin will ever be less than perfect. And the tomato salsa and tortilla chips, from reading other reviews it seems we were lucky not to have stale chips, but they weren't and were delicious. We also got the Pork pibil tacos which are insanely good! Flavourful, porky and so juicy! The Herring tostadas, delicious, the fresh marinaded smoked herring is so gooood. The Chorizo & potato quesadilla, which I wouldn't have chosen reading it from the menu, but I'm glad someone did! It wasn't at all as potato-y and heavy as it sounds. And the Chicken wings a la mojo which were incredibly moreish and perfectly lifted with a squeeze of lime.Basically it's all good!

ZBqjU4z8u95N9zivdu9i4A.text: Coming from California, I've really missed good Mexican food while living in Europe. Although Wahaca isn't quiet the authentic Mexican you'd find in southern San Diego, it is definitely a respectable substitute. There are some great taco options that are good for sharing with friends. One of the best margaritas I've had over here too!The atmosphere is what makes this place so fun. The young crowd gives Wahaca an energetic buzz and overall good vibes. It is the perfect spot to grab a bite to eat before a night out with friends.

0uQNPkLVnjD_D418FCIqjQ.text: I have been to both the Covent Garden and Soho Branches of Wahaca and I prefer Soho for atmosphere and space. I have found it has generally been much quicker to get a table here and the food has been slightly better here. Wahaca can never be criticized for having a lack of flavour or presentation where its food is concerned but sometimes the quality has been notable. For example sometimes things have been a little too soggy or just slightly over or undercooked. But then I do remind myself that when there is a lot of orders on then sometimes things aren't as perfect as when you last had them. I hold no issues at all with this and I will say that there has never been a case where it has become shockingly bad, but when you are used to something being at a certain level then it spoils us in many ways. What I refuse to fault Wahaca on is price as well as diversity of choice in the menu. Only I have found that with many visits this winter I am keen to see what the new menu has in store. My advice to anyone is where possible to try and eat at Wardour Street if in central. In terms of things I adore on the menu, the Churros, Tortilla Soup and the taquitos always seem to find themselves on my receipt at the end of the meal. I am determined to try the fish taco's and tamales on my next visit, although recently I did experience a rather nice steak but I wasn't overly enthralled with the rice. It was pleasant but it didn't excite me in the ways I was expecting it to. Oh and do try the hibiscus drink too. It is like drinking rubies in a glass.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

kkiy7mLBXuv88LncXM1Axg.text: How have I, as a North American, lived in London for a whole year and not yet tried Wahaca until today?!I had heard mixed reviews about London's most famous mexican chain, so I set my standards pretty low before going in. I'm happy to say I was pleasantly surprised!We ordered nibbles for the whole table and had a tapas-style lunch overlooking the river. The potato and chorizo quesadillas were delish, as were the pork tacos. The punchy and fresh salsa was also a highlight.Super fast and friendly service and everyone left happy.No complaints!

xx0rB7HTPSVtzv8UdXi2zg.text: This is the saddest review yet. I wanted to be knocked over by this place. The food is fresh, the service is on par and the prices are almost too low. The flavour was just not there. The spices were missing. I love Tomasina Meiers (surely misspelled).  Her passion for Mexico, it's cuisine and the wonderful people is infectious. Her show gives me culinary inspiration nightly. But the taste was just not there. The food, in my opinion, needs more cilantro, cumin and heat. The bottled sauce were spectacular however. The drinks are great. And the staff is really good. This is a nice place.Perhaps it's just me.  Maybe the tastes I am after are available only in East Los Angeles and Baja Norte. The food is good by London Mexican food Standards. But I wanted more. I am sorry dear Tomasina.

G3tY-gmnKnIollhPaCNHDQ.text: Great food and a really good selection if you're a vegetarian (as long as you love all your food covered in feta that is). Had a rather rude and dismissive bartender doing her best not to serve us any drinks before the meal but the food was so good this more than made up for this.

SrJ458p-PMlgzpT-IfSJcg.text: Wahaca is a solid option for Mexican in Soho, with great food (that is good value for money)! I've been here a few times now... I love the street food menu, where you can pick 2-3 smaller things to enjoy as a meal, and their larger courses are good as well. Great drinks too-- reasonably priced cocktails for this part of town! The vanilla passion fruit mojito is awesome. Funky, large dining space, with very attentive service and friendly staff. Great for groups. Recommend if you fancy Mexican. Only negative is the place can get a bit loud, as it is large and quite busy!

QvkXvRvVvCjtfZJlFAaitw.text: I really enjoyed this place. Went in a group of eight on a Saturday evening (a little on the late side, close to 10pm, and we didn't need to wait long for a table).Friendly and attentive service.Great food, fresh and tasty, in decent portions.Lively and buoyant. Good value.A good spot to go for any type of occasion, I would say. Highly recommended.
