O1RB063cgxFNarvz7D1how.text: I would give this place four stars for providing London with decent Mexican food but the service here was very slow so they deserve these three stars. I tried this place the last time I visited London because my friend had a huge craving for burritos, as it's difficult to find decent Mexican food in the UK, and I was interested in tasting what this place had to offer, coming from California.I got a chicken burrito and it was pretty small and was pressed (new experience for me). It was just OK, I'm sure if this was your only source of Mexican food it would be a pretty good experience for you. It was pretty crowded so I assume it's popular with the local folk :P Maybe I should have gone with some of their small plates instead of what I was acquainted with from back home, but whaatever! Their bar was pretty crowded so I'm guessing they have good drinks here, come here if you're craving mexican food and are looking for a social night :)

ISjzmUV4yStjVtEBczosFA.text: Such a great fan of this Mexican chain!! Great food and service! And when you pay you get a small package of chili seeds to grow your very own peppers!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

7CLDhZ1txSGbsbdNw-PdGg.text: Definitely one of the best places I have eaten in London. Fairly decent selection, good service, friendly bartenders. and good food. I came in for dinner and there was a short wait. I was told I could wait at the bar upstairs till me table was ready. I ordered a regular margarita and it was delicious. The bartenders were studying for an exam and for my second round offered me a different margarita and they were spot on it was delicious. I later went to my table and ordered some nachos with salsa; I also asked for some hot peppers because I like it spicy. The brought me a small bowl of red chilies which were delicious. Service was a  little rushed so I only give them 4 stars. The restaurant was clean. firly wel lit, and had some culturee correct music playing. My dinner was a slow-cooked pork burrito - it was labeled spicy but it was not. So once again I was happy to have asked for peppers at the beginning of my meal. All and all a great dining experience with god prices and a great atmosphere. I hope to come to this place again for another meal and more drinks. If you want good food at a good price and don't mind being rushed; this is the place to go!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Slow-cooked pork. Pretty good :)
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Salsa, chips, and margarita .. Yummy!

BS81qaB2USWMu55zdcPLcA.text: I was completely won over by the interior design of Wahaca. The toilets alone resemble a Roman sanitation system, with a contemporary take. The restaurant itself is spacious, light and modern. The menu was really long and exciting. After some great Mexican food at Lupita's, my friend and I were eager to try out more authentic food. I ordered the vegetarian cactus and corn burrito-at £6.50 it seemed like a good deal. My friend took the steak burrito. We got some guacamole on the side, which we didn't realise they would charge us for (but they charged us a hefty £2.95 for a small bowl).The burrito was okay, but a bit on the small side, and the tortilla chips did little to excite me. The refried beans were a bit bland and seemed to be the main component of the burrito. The rice tasted a little bit too processed. I poured a lot of the hot sauce on my burrito to improve the taste but I think the burrito was also a bit on the sloppy side, lacking crunchy and tasty vegetables. I would give wahaca another try, they have horchata on the menu for only £1.75, a relative steal. Otherwise, quite a forgettable experience.

DZo4L4YaUltRjwM4fMEcoA.text: Came here from my friend recommending to try their Michelada, which is indeed not too bad itself matching with a Corona. Guacamole was made fresh, and the tortilla chips were fried to just the right amount, leaning towards more of a thick cut. The wait is quite long, so a cocktail drink or two is kind of an expected move.For their dishes, I would definitely recommend Sweet potato & feta taquito. MM The feta cheese was soooo good, the mix of sweet and salty was just to the right amount. Portions were alright as well. Pork taco and winter vegetable tacos were mediocre, my friends would recommend the pork one, which was said to be marinated quite well. Be aware that the wrapping is corn tortilla, so the texture of the wrapper is softer and chewier. Huitlacoche was also quite good, two of these cheese and mushroom quasadillas, though nothing specially really. The MSC Fish burrito wasn't the best, not sure if the fish wasn't fresh enough or what not, but in my opinion not worth the £7. all in all, 5 dishes between the 3 of us were just quite enough with a happy and fair tap to split among us. Oh, the dishes also came fairly quick. Lastly, their hotcake dessert is a must get. God! The combination of dulce de leche and sprinkled with caramelised peanuts is heavenlyyyyyy! Also, do try the plantain corn tortilla dessert thingy! Glazed with honey mmmM!Not sure if I'd come again, but do drop by if you're around southbank for a nice social night!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

v1Qe-HAtNngxA-MLXxnohA.text: So first day in London went to this restaurant. My friend had recommended it and I had it on my bookmarks also. We had to wait for 30mins for out table. Waiting area is downstairs which there is fusball table and bar. Once we got table we had a look at menu and our waiter came to introduce himself. Bruno, fantastic guy. I had tacos with sweet potato fries with ginger beer. Food is delicious, fries were the highlight if my meal. Tacos were delicious but portion was quite small. Now the bad points.....ginger beer was terrible, did not like it at all. Price is also not worth it. Now food is amazing but portions are really small and I was still hungry. I had to go get a sandwich after cause didn't want spend more money here and still be hungry after. Services were great and reccomend this place but don't go if you are really hungry and expect to be full with a meal. Unless you willing to spend more.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. sweet potato fries delicious
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

VThR0PKz5kNgp6D-Kt3neQ.text: Loved it. Place was busy but got a table for 1 in 5 minutes. Had guacamole dip and chips with three slow pork tacos with spicy pickled pink onion. Tacos were incredible. Little smaller than in Mexico and US but very filling. Had a Hibiscus soft drink. Good music, lots of young groups with lively conversation in the room that had a vibrant colorful atmosphere. Staff was friendly and efficient.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Slow cooked pork tacos with spicy pickled onions

GivY0IqzwmU5HurtMLxzzg.text: Wahaca really exceeded my expectations and standards for Mexican fare in London. Being from Texas, I can be borderline picky and difficult-to-please when it comes to Mexican food. I was seriously craving some Mexican food in the middle of my London stay and I noticed that Wahaca came up frequently in my search. I was a little wary, seeing that it was a prolific chain but it definitely is a tasty and affordable choice for Mexican-style food and drinks in London.The interior of the restaurant is very colorful but has a nice and airy feel to it. I was expecting a more cramped, dive-y ambiance but there was lots of space. I can imagine that even when it is packed with customers, it doesn't feel too cramped. Wahaca's cuisine is definitely more Mexican-style than pure Mexican food. Many of the dishes are contain ingredients that wouldn't necessarily be found on menus in Mexico, but all of the staple dishes -tacos, burritos, enchiladas, quesadillas, etc.- appear on the menu in various forms. I like that half of the menu is small dishes, so you can order a couple and sample a variety of food. I was really hungry so I had two small plates and a side- the chipotle chicken quesadillas, plantain tacos, and roasted sweet potatoes. The standout was definitely the plantain tacos. I'm a plantain lover and the spicy salsa on the tacos was the perfect combination. The salsa had a spicy kick. The quesadillas were nice and cheesy, but otherwise not too exciting or different from what you'd expect. The roasted sweet potatoes were flavorful and perfectly roasted. I also ordered the vanilla-passionfruit mojito was fruity and strong. All of the cocktails sounded delicious and were reasonably-priced, even outside of happy hour. The service at Wahaca was incredibly polite and attentive. My server was so sweet. Most of the staff seemed eager to attend every customer. Overall, this was one of the better meals I had in London. Definitely the best Mexican food I have had in London in my many trips over the years.

khcxrohqPW_fNKQhPovZnw.text: Every year I make it a point to visit London, my favorite city I've ever visited, and every year I make it a point to eat at Wahaca. I really like the whole street style menu and the friendly and fast waiters, who gladly will explain the whole concept for first timers wearing a nice smile on their faces. If you're into hot, Mexican street food or just curious about the concept, I would definitely recommend that you check this place out. Their prices are reasonable and you don't have to order a whole lot, if you aren't that hungry. The places is always busy and be prepared for ore try loud surroundings, when the place is busy. I am coming back next year and will again happily eat at Wahaca, it's pretty much a tradition of mine now :)

zNQGhmbosNWO07p4N5Rkzw.text: Azulito bar has lots of choice for cocktails and they also do micheladas (beer with lime, salt and chilly).We had a big group reservation, the restaurant was full, even though the food came fast.My favourite dish is Pork Pibil tacos!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Azulito bar

7rryqf8j0RGKRnKPhB00Gg.text: My friends and I originally planned to go to a Time Out-rated burger place, but ended up going to Wahaca instead.  It was one of the better choices that we could have made for sure.With modern and spacious interior, the restaurant didn't come across as your average Mexican franchise; rather, it almost felt like a legitimate Mexican restaurant.  The menu was very well-balanced across tacos, taquitos, quesadillas, burritos, bigger mains, etc. Furthermore, given that most everything came in tapas-sized portions, we were able to try out a little bit of everything.  I'd particularly recommend the pork taquitos, chicken quesadilas, and the specials they have on a separate menu.  The classic margaritas we ordered on the size were impeccable as well.  Last but not least, service was great; our waiter checked on us regularly and was kind.All in all, a solid place I'd go back to when I have cravings for Mexican food.

l2iAqniWZ_3Zk5UoiR4-3g.text: Great reasonably priced Mexican for London. The location is very casual, the food solid and the beers cold ;) Excellent view and location on SouthBank.Tip from our waiter Jose, Steak from the grill, as I am Canadian wasn't expecting much for that price in London, 5 stars, excellent rub, cooked perfectly medium rare! Yum!!

wQ_gkkrWCUtC41mLm1qZvQ.text: I'm not so impressed, but the meal was so-so and the service was okay so 3 stars it is. When we first arrived, we waited almost 10 minutes for a server, but when he did come he was very sweet and helpful. The food was not bad, but also not great, and that might be because I live in Southern California and get to eat amazingly authentic Mexican food regularly. For a night out with friends, this is a fun spot, just not the most authentic.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Black bean tostadas were just okay
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Mushroom quesadilla and the rice and beans were good
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork tacos (delicious and a bit spicy) and winter vegetable tacos (just okay)

l22Rlw1_lM8bmtCDvEVPNw.text: Thank the heavens for Wahaca (Oaxaca), It saved me from shriveling up and turning into a spiteful monster wandering the streets of London. I should preface this review with the following info about me. I'm originally from southern California and Mexican food made up a good portion of our weekly meal choices. So that being said 1 month in London without GOOD mexican food was like getting breathing air again after a month without. Thats how much I value good mexican food, and not just me but my hubby too. But I digress. Back to the food. I was with fellow yelper Dza D at the Soho restaurant we ordered:3 orders of the Pork tacos1 order of the chicken tacos1 chicken quesadilla1 quacamole2 Jaimaica Or Hibiscus waterThe chicken quesadilla was tasty, with a sweet sorta bbq sauce with cheese and chicken. It was a great starter. I got the drier end and my companion got the wetter side so it was really drippy on him, but that could've been eating style too. Not sure what happened, but I thoroughly enjoyed my half. The Pork tacos were bomb. nice cut of meat with pickled onions on top with cilantro. The chicken tacos were the same thing as the quesadilla but without the melty cheesy goodness. I thought they were seriously lacking and just too much sauce. For dessert I had to try to the Churro con Chocolate, it was more savory and less sweet cinnamon that what i was expecting and wanting. Over all a really great meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Super nice bathrooms
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork Tacos

URRbI1tvIgTGGdtvG3GO9g.text: Great environment downstairs with music and delicious margaritas, but upstairs in the restaurant the experience was not very pleasant. I was given a dirty glass for my water that smelled AWFUL and then the enchiladas I ordered were swimming in cream sauce, had poor quality chicken bits, and lacked much flavor. wish I had gotten the smaller street food plates.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Enchiladas

dnUAewAHwg_s_0ZpQ5rQ2g.text: My husband and I ate here a few months back and we really liked it! There were a lot of great options on the menu and the staff was very helpful and accommodating. We tried a variety of small plates which were all delicious and the service was quick. We would definitely eat here again!

z0JWXmb7-FxcrKNQKdCAVA.text: Wahaca turned out to be a great place for an affordable and fun dinner with my girlfriends before going out for drinks and dancing in Soho. You can't reserve a table but there's a cool bar downstairs where you can have a yummy Margarita until your buzzer goes off. I ordered an amazing veggie salad served in a taco shell. The salad has amazing flavours and if you want a lighter version you just don't have the taco shell but it's kinda irresistable! I'll definitely go again and won't need to look at the menu because my heart beats for Margarita and the taco shell salad only.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The Taco Shell Salad

uJpoM7F-r6idHV8dzWwkYA.text: I wanted to try this restaurant because I had heard a lot of great things about this place online. This Mexican street food chain was started by the 2005 BBC Masterchef winner and has multiple locations around London.For some reason I was expecting it to be a little like Chipotle (upscale fast food), but it's actually more of a trendy sit down restaurant. There's great eclectic and colorful decor in the SoHo store and the restaurant was pretty dim for dinner. The menu is setup to try multiple items like Mexican tapas. The steak tacos were good and the chicken taquitos were tasty as well. I didn't get a chance to try the churos and chocolate but that dessert item sounded good.Of course nowhere can compare the street Mexican food in Southern California, but I thought this place was pretty good. There's a fun ambiance and you get to try a lot of different Mexican dishes in a more upscale atmosphere than a Mexican food truck. The overall cost isn't cheap but it also isn't that expensive. I'm not from London so I don't know the food scene here that well, but my impression is that there aren't a lot of Mexican restaurants here that serve this same type of food. I would recommend trying out this place if you want to eat Mexican and want to go somewhere fun.

_svKDLYAbTKUYdvpGvMBLg.text: It was ok. nothing special.I can cook in similar quality...

m_qNqUx1duVL70oW0kSmpQ.text: This is the first time I've been to Wahaca and I'll definitely be going back. I was already into the idea of Mexican food but never found a good place in London.Wahaca is just what I was looking for. For a start they have a wide range of Tequila and Mezcal and their house brand El Tesoro is top of the range but not top price (I would go for the reposado not the blanco). I just found out that Sainsbury's only stock the very ordinary Jose Cuervo or the marginally better Sauza brands, so I'll popping over to Wahaca for a good tequila fix and they know their agaves there! The food was delicious too: really good guacamole, delicious garlicy mushrooms in cheese and I loved the meatballs! Wahaca means a great night out on a date, with friends or even if you are just visiting London. Viva la revolucion!

vYOETvUbNDOweQ7Jb1KepA.text: Great Mexican food at affordable prices and not too spicy (which was good for me, though you can have it spicy if that's how you like your food)! Also quite a few vegetarian options, which was also great for me. The Vegetarian Quesadilla with beans and cheese was my favourite!Really nice atmosphere and interior. Also liked the fact that you can order several portions of different dishes and then share with your friends.Will definitely go there again soon!

7QtBDhyZdgKHbobF9mFgRQ.text: I don't get out much being a mum with a small child, but when I do I like good food with an upbeat but relaxed child friendly atmosphere.  Wahaca ticked all the right boxes.  Even though they were closing early for New Years Eve we were not rushed to place the order and given plenty of time to eat, drink and be merry.

zWbIDbrI5HEERUXigMIuoA.text: Wahaca-ooga-chaka-ooga-chaka-ooga-chaka... One of the chants you may hear from customers gorging on the mexican delights inside; their mouths full of Chorizo and Churros, the Corona helping as a lubricant to produce this strange noise. I like Wahaca. It's fun and they don't try and stick a sombrero on your head whilst shaking their maraca's in your face to compensate for the pallid, mess of a burrito the chef is trying to dress whilst smoking a cigar. Ok so enough of the stereotypes. But isn't that the problem with a lot of Mexican restaurant's? Wahaca is different. It has blonde hair. A sleek, slender figure, and porcelain smooth skin. No hirsute appearance. No hint of flabby belly hanging out of the garish, floral shirt. It doesn't require that you stay until morning and exchange numbers as you make for the door sheepishly. It looks good, tastes even better and knows it. It is just happy you are there and selflessly wants you to fulfil one of your basic needs as quickly as you desire. The decor is quirky but minimal and the service prompt but not to the point you ever feel rushed. Darrn, the waiter had been to our table 3 times before I had even ordered and he didn't even so much as puff cigar smoke in my face in disgust. We opted, (once I had finally ordered), for the tapas style dishes; little tasters of authentic street-food cuisine costing around £3.95-£5.00 (gee's they must have some rich but well-fed vagrants in mexico!!)First was the slow cooked pork pilbil tacos, chorizo and potato quesadillas and then the street food special - Queso Fundido with (garlicky mushrooms in a cheesy taco). Aariba-aariba! What tasty offerings from the gods!  Imagine the Spice Girls were writing around in your mouth, naked, and then you get the picture! You can go for the whole Burito, Fajita experience if you want to be a little greedy but in all honesty there was more than enough here. In future I would try the sharing platter though (which I have heard is Kerry Katona satisfyingly huge), just for, erm 'research' purposes you know! I left satiated; slightly larger and merrier. My t-shirt saturated with a pork and potato congealed mess! Added 21/01: We did finish off with a warm and sticky portion of Churros (NOT the breakfast cereal!!) - well it would be rude not to!

MvpAsrfwT2VmVCit3MkT-w.text: Once seated, we got off to a bad start with a rather brusque waitress, who crossed that fine line between efficient and unpleasant with considerable aplomb. The waitress may well have 'explained' the menu and how to order, but she spoke so fast, and with such a strong accent that it was impossible to follow. Anyway, I'd been to Wahaca's before so knew what to order. Before long our food came, with the typical Wagamama's style trade mark of haphazard, staggered delivery. Chorizo and potato quesadilla: this was supremely cheesy, with not much chorizo flavor, but all round general yummiest. I'm a big fan of this. Black bean and cheese quesadilla: Rather too much black bean compared to cheese, and the flavor became a little monotonous quite quickly. Needs more flavoring or spice. Green rice: Ignore the fact this rice seems rather boil in the bag and a little cooler than expected  the flavoring of herbs in this rice is fantastic. It acts as a perfect foil to the cheesier parts of the menu. Sweet potato chunks: Delicious. Cooked till tender then deep fried with herbs and spices, these are crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and the sweet taste is not overpowering. One of my friends did get a dessert, which will be familiar to anyone who has been to La Tasca. Churros (doughnut twists deep fried) with a dark chocolate dipping sauce. Delicious, but greasy. If you don't mind the grease smeared all over your fingers, then you won't mind this dessert at all. All in all, the service was unimpressive, but I will be back, as I've always had great service before.

7YshTe-oZvnkVg0OCwwvVQ.text: As a massive fan of Mexican food because I have lived in California for years and enjoyed very authentic Mexican cooking, I'm grateful to Thomasina Miers (founder of Wahaca) for spearheading the wave of delicious, authentic Mexican cuisine in London.The food here is mostly great, especially the fantastically fresh salsa and super creamy guacamole. The Tortilla chips are moreish but the pork rinds, I warn you, are not. They will break your teeth! Dreadful! But do try everything else as it is all delicious and as realistic a rendition of proper Mexican food that you are going to get in London.ps the Margaritas are out of this world!

ZG58ds7bJ-YyAFwOYJF01w.text: Excellent food, excellent value. The senora salad is to die for! A firm favourite. The hibiscus water is a great healthy drink ( especially if u'r trying to be healthy for january!). Not the place for a romantic,quiet dinner. Its loud, its proud & its brilliant!Love you Thomasina!

L_Zirwuv3Owfuz_HsfZmsw.text: Great pork tacos and chicken taquitos! Not as good as cali mex but phenomenal by London standards

syMdE9200Ib5lNnmt5EvJg.text: I wasn't blown away but it's probably the best Mexican I've had in London.

NKelaDsZ6quPZD28cvOq3g.text: Wow. I'd heard good things about this place and I wasn't disappointed. Great food - and plenty to choose from, including delicious desserts and diamond drinks. Excellent service and a cool interior too. If you like Mexican food, this place is a dream. If you don't like it, go anyway. You'll be converted.

Lvme_Pbm1VZe4heo8Lgy2g.text: The burritos were great, but take a pass on the fish tacos, unless you want a sort of deep fried fish (that you could get at any fish and chip shop). Drink sizes seem a bit small and pricey, but overall good quality. Our server also forgot to bring our requested Guacamole to the table until we were almost done with our meal, which reflects poorly on Wahaca, but I understand that it may have been the server forgot.

TwKFZIylB-0jxdEqJ_YZ-A.text: I absolutely love Wahaca. The food is always fresh, their signature cocktails are great and the service has always been impeccable. Added to that the price is more than reasonable. Possibly the best cheap eat in London.

iHVBOXNDTL11YJZec_TOgg.text: This is the place i always take my friends when they first come to visit me in London, the food is cheap and the service has always been good. I must point out that you cannot book tables, but I always believe its worth the wait.

a8OpGVcGzprDiy3aBkwNcw.text: great food, more than reasonable prices for Soho.  The best Mexican food I've had in London.  We ordered tapas style so we could try everything.  Black beans were very good, as was the chorizo quesadillas. each had 2-3 drinks with a dessert to share and our bill was around 30 quid each.

G-Vz82fih4pZr0_qzl6KEg.text: This is my favorite Mexican restaurant in London town. I have eaten in both Covent Garden and Soho locations and would recommend to all my friends. I prefer the decor/design and layout of the Soho locale and the visuals throughout compliment the vibrant atmosphere. This is a great place to go and feast, sample and share the flavorful food with your friends/partners/family/sister from another mister and brother from another mothers. Make sure to pick up and plant your matches!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Wahaca Soho

EOViYR_DTwX4ZyaQm3EJDg.text: I've only had one previous experience of Wahaca years ago at the branch at Westfield and it was a bit, meh!  That time I had a burrito and I have to say it did nothing for me. Unperturbed my wife and I went again recently for a pre theatre quick eat and run type meal and I thoroughly enjoyed it. The ceviche starter I ordered was far from authentic being served on a tortilla chip (which made it a bit messy) but it tasted delicious and my British steak done the Mexican way (their title not mine) was a revelation, char grilled but lovely and pink served with green rice which was delicious. My only real complaint would have to be that the portions aren't huge so if you hungry you may want to think about an extra side. Oh and try the churros with chocolate sauce, I know it's difficult to mess up a deep fried dough dessert but these are delicious.

XEVnRpaUwdrOxHweaAZEVw.text: HORRIBLE. We got our food late. The portions were as if we ordered from a kids menu. It didnt taste anything like mexican food. They had advertised that they got ideas from los angeles, but it was no way near L.A. mexican food. There was a waiter there that was so rude. I had a horrible experience. It almost ruined my london experience. I hope they close down soon.

3p_JRaf8thZcI0KbJyE4Rg.text: As a Californian visiting London, I'm cutting this place some slack. That said, everything we had was pretty good, if certain things were better than others. Quesadilla was poor. Sweet potato taquitos were tasty. Pork scratchings with guacamole were amusing. There's certainly someone who appreciates real Mexican food behind the menu here, even if the execution is lacking at times. That said, this was some of the better restaurant food I ate in London.

MAONzEvPrqYU1GWK-ubjhw.text: This is not Mexican food. It's not Tex Mex. It's like that kids toy from the 80s where you put slices of bread in and out came bread shaped like McDonald's fries. Those weren't fries. This is Mexican food-shaped blah. If you absolutely must eat and there is nothing else around and you do not have a kitchen or are too incompetent to cook then you may find some enjoyment eating here. Or, if you are made of money and love tequila then you might enjoy some of the Mexican tequilas they have on offer which are admittedly hard to come by. But otherwise, just go to Tortilla, Chipotle, Chilango, Poncho #8, Cafe' Pacifico, Lupita, Daddy Donkey, Adobo, Cantina Laredo or even Las Iguanas.

T3NES6rcP7WWNWJI6eTwtg.text: This was a really good mexican food. I had mexican tacos, burritos, quesadillas and lots more in the U.S. especially in California and this restaurant is really good, even it is in the U.K. :-)

tg6nmf3ODBsWFCdTZh5Y1Q.text: I wasn't sure what to make of this place at first. Mexican food, in London.  I've had Mexican in Mexico City, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and other places that are hard to beat. Have to say, the fresh ingredients and authentic style impressed me.  A solid margarita (nice and salty rim), a good quesedilla, and some friendly service. Seems like they're paying attention to the details.When I saw a couple fooseball tables downstairs, I knew I would come back on the next visit to London.  The washrooms are also sexy, although I wasn't sure what to do at first.

cOXpfQxatj6CSQerJ3iphg.text: I visited the Soho branch of Wahaca on Monday as part of a Qype event - and what a fun night we had! I've been a massive fan of Mexican food ever since I first set foot into the Wahaca in Covent Garden a couple of years back; however, I think the Soho branch has the edge now that I've been as it seems a lot more spacious. Our event consisted of a screening of the second episode of Mexican Food Made Simple (hosted by wahaca founder Tommi) down in the basement bar of the restaurant. It's a very nice space with it's own bar, so definitely worth visiting while you are waiting for a table in the pstairs restaurant. First, the guacamole....YUM! I could happily have stuck with this all night. Well, I would have done if it wasn't for the delicious salsa (for which we were given the ingredients for in a goody bag), the broad been and feta quesadillas and the very moreish pork pibils (if anyone has the recipe please do message me!) that we were plied with for most of the evening. Plus there were the tequila-tastic cocktails. I wouldn't normally drink 4 cocktails on a Monday night but (in the name of research) I'm happy to report that I awoke without a hint of a hangover. Overall, I will DEFINITELY be heading back to Wahaca Soho soon. The food was great and the staff couldn't have been more welcoming. Thoroughly recommended!

_aV0-RYaB6J824_UHaJXSA.text: For some reason, I associate the word "Mexican" with some chaos -- even in the culinary context. Wahaca is not like that: it's well decorated, cozy and has soothing background music. That being said, they have great dishes (though not awesome) & service, and accessible prices. I think I will visit here more often.

r5g9ulZ3KUthdzut8dBGYA.text: nice mexican in the centre of London, I enjoyed a lot the quesadillas :)

13uK51HATk3mf0KFGkQPZQ.text: I came here for drinks a couple of weeks ago. I haven't eaten here, and I hear such good things about the food. But the bar? Not so much. It's not that it's a bad bar, it's spacious and great if you've got a large group. But the bar staff annoyed me. While I understand that making more than one drink is sensible, it's really NOT if you're trying to make three different orders at once. From three people who don't know each other. I don't care that you've messed up someone else's order if you were serving me first. I'm just standing there getting pissed off while you're handing my credit card to someone else. And I still don't have my drink yet. The drinks are cheap (£6.50 for a mojito), and they're tasty. But I'll only drink them when I order food. I'm not likely to come back to the bar again until they sort out the service.

sn5WbiuZ7Nh2jY_t-KtMhA.text: Visited SBC shipping containers last nightSad.Style over substanceTries so hard to be cool and failsFirstly-weak insipid formulaic Margherita-no kick or taste of freshness- like drinking lime cordial.Probably the worst meal/ service and experience I have had in London for agesLukewarm mush served with no charm, or knowledge by frenzied staff who had seemingly no knowledge of anything at all.I know a restaurant is bad when no-one at any point in the whole evening says' how is it'Dodgy nachos that tasted like they were left over from a kids party the day before.Dull insipid salsa- where's the freshness and heat and the kick?Burritos with chicken lukewarm and filed with mushSides horrid - my black beans looked like they had been regurgitated by someone's chihuahua.Bad veggie choices too.Two of my party didn't eat in the end.Food came randomly and so quickly it was hard to believe it hadn't been pre preparedI've had good Mexican food before but this certainly was not itClearly designed for the 'get pissed quickly' tourist market of the South-bank - If that's your aim then good luck to youA waste of 140 quid for a pile of mushAt least the beers were cold!

N4Boo4idfvp10TdFezJZTQ.text: Amazing Mexican street food! Pork Pibils are the best. Really cool bar/ football table area downstairs (which isn't open on Sundays)...

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

b3CPxS5Eo7iTR4DCd9pIng.text: What is it about Wahaca that isn't perfect? The lovely tequila bar in the lower level has a great piece of art in the form of hanging chains. It both screens the bathroom area and livens up the area with colour. The lower area then leads into the tequila bar which can hold a surprisingly large number of people whole still feeling small and intimate. Where else can you sip quality tequila in a hanging wicker basket? Upstairs there is an amazingly huge restaurant area where they serve some of the most delicious Mexican street food around. The best part of the delicious dinner is, of course, the churros. These delicious deep fried doughnuts with cinnamon sugar come with a lovely thick chocolate sauce that you dip them in to. They are worth visiting Wahaca for on their own. Just settle down, order a tequila and grab some of these delicious morsels of deep fried goodness. YUM!

cGHOMtja5iU8I5CzZfVEZA.text: The first few times I tried to get a table at their Covent Garden branch; it always being über -busy and my stomach being impatient, I normally admitted defeat. But good things come to those who wait; it's a fantastic place to catch up with friends, always buzzing and the streetfood principle mean serving is informal and sharing is encouraged  if you were an only child please take note. With the opening of their Wardour St branch brings comfort to know there's back-up a short skip away. Previously a non-descript boozer, the place was stripped down and as much as possible of the old building was incorporated into the new design, which was commissioned to individual designers to give it a vibrant feel. For some reason I was particularly impressed with the design of the toilets; make of that what you will! Being more of a whiskey man I was scandalously ignorant the tequila process and, very much like the uisce beatha, the intricacies which can be involved, which resulting in a wide range of flavours. Contrast that to my previous encounters which normally involved a glass being pushed into my hand with dash of salt and a sliver of citrus well past the bewitching hour. The house tequila, El Tesoro, is highly recommended; compliments superbly the best of Mexican grub on offer. So if you haven't tried Wahaca yet, sort it out: are you a Mexican, or a Mexican't?!

AJNiEgDvvNIT0W7ryXovSw.text: I've now been to all of London's Wahaca ... and can highly recommend them all. The Soho location is (or at least seems to be) the most spacious. And with its Wardour Street address, it's certainly the most convenient for me. The food's just as yummy as at their other three locations ... and of course the cocktails and drinks list is top notch. The downstairs bar is a very comfy and fun setting and incredibly roomy for such a central bit of Soho. Like tequila? Or don't think you've given it a fair shake in the past? The friendly folks at Wahaca not only take their menu of Mexican yummies seriously; they're also incredibly keen to spread the word that good tequila is good stuff: london.blog.qype.com/201…  A great restaurant to keep in mind whether just popping in for a quick bite or planning a proper fiesta.

fi6kts4U6tNhzxc3t20EMw.text: I loved it! We were invited to celebrate the launch of Mexican Food Made Simple. Sarah from Qype was a perfect host and made us feel very welcome!The food and drinks were mouthwatering. The decor was fun, with a spinny chair disguised as a pot! People were friendly and we had so much laughter! I felt like I was on holiday!The goody bag was such a nice surprise and I really enjoyed making the salsa after watching how Tommi did it!I love love loved it! Thank you so much!

LqbV4qpM-4efyYIG99pmWA.text: We were here on Monday night for the screening of an episode of co-owner Thomasina Miers Mexican cooking show. We spent all night in the downstairs bar enjoying (tequila filled)cocktails, I'd recommend the Mayan Gold, it tasted fantastic and packed a punch. After enjoying the drinks, tortilla chips and outstanding Salsa we spend the next 30 minutes watching the show, which is well worth tuning into. Once the program finished we we treated to some excellent tacos, quesadillas and other treats, all of which we fantastic and did a pretty good job soaking up all the tequila we had consumed. On our way out we were given a goodie bag containing everything we needed to make the salsa Thomasina made on the show. All in all it was a fantastic night and Wahaca is always a pleasure to visit!

FIsHN6xsESWhlf2pzxXPsQ.text: Whenever people say they want Mexican, I insist we go to Wahaca. I have a feeling that the Covent Garden branch might be slightly better in terms of food, but the tequila bar in the Soho branch is a true highlight.Since the lines tend to be monumental for dinner, it was a great idea to create a sort of hangout space for people to wait until their buzzer rings.

pdsdnX-SWdVYx0EpkQiluQ.text: Foodwise this branch of Wahaca is still what they are everywhere else - tasty. The reason why this one interests me is the bar downstairs. I rather like tequila and while popularity is rising, the number of bars who do something with tequila seems to not be going up at the same rate, so another one appearing on the scene, below a restaurant or not, is to be praised. By me at least. I like tequila. And churros. I was along for a Qype-y tequila tasting and while a bunch of the things I tried will have a wide path steered around them in the future, there were some that really tickled my palate that will hopefully be appearing on their menu soon. The range of what we tasted suggests that you should be able to find at least one tequila that'll be up your street. Wahaca are looking to find new and interesting drinks that you probably won't have had before and for that I'm a dedicated fan. And the churros. For the time being they have El Tesoro heading a range of different flavours and styles of tequila, as well as a couple of Mezcals for those after something a bit different. The cocktail list adds a tequila twist to a bunch of classics and also includes a rather tasty margarita. They still don't take bookings so when you're inevitably waiting for a table pop down to the bar and drink some tasty mexican beverages.

Mf8lyxhZ7Ve4JpVdZdlTvQ.text: I wish there was a half star option.  3 seems too little but 4 seems too much.  It's a valiant effort at authentic Mexican (or Mexican cum California) and out of all the London haunts that have sprung up hocking tacos, these guys are close to the top.Carnitas tacos are pretty dead-on.  Other bits and pieces take dramatic license but still end up being tasty.The big no-no for me is the fish taco.  It's rare to see a fish taco in London and I was praying these guys would nail it.  Alas, when it arrived it was very much English fish n chips in a tortilla.  Don't get me wrong.  I love fish n chips.  I just like it when it's larger.  And not in a tortilla.  And when it's served with tartar sauce.  And chips.Blah blah blah.  Whatever.  It does the trick.For burritos, I'd go to Chipotle.  The one location in London that's actually killing it.  Much better than Chipotle in the States.

UyfXhzdN5XI_60l2UvAjyw.text: Lovely space & decor, wait staff was a delight.My pro-tip for a great lunch for one: order 3 starters, like some tacos, tostadas, and something else. You get a lot of fun variety and flavors, plenty of food, and you do not feel super food.

uHR5l_ApceiySvMjrg_00g.text: Nom nom!  (that's chewing noises).  Best Mexican I've had in London for sure.

utnloX-9fHBxddchIKKc-g.text: I've only ever been to the flagship Wahaca in Covent Garden, and after checking out the Wardour St branch the other night, I think I may have discovered another little gem right in the heart of Soho. A great vibe - even for a Tuesday night! The pork tacos were as tasty as I remembered, and the dessert of creme caramel was pretty flan-tastico, while the churros con chocolate probably needed an extra sprinkle of cinnamon sugar to get my Gourmet Belly singing Olé! The no reservations policy still stands, although with a fantastic space in the downstairs bar area complete with hanging chairs, fussball tables and an extensive cocktail list with Tequila making a strong presence, I don't think you'd have a problem passing time while you wait for a table.

mOpyU3fGfPOOfTw31xj-Fw.text: It's difficult to describe an experience at Wahaca - just cast the idea of the bog-standard Mexican restaurants that you find around town out of your mind. There are no fake cactuses and sombreros here - just serious interior design and equally serious attention to detail with their range of mexican 'street food', equalled by a passion for sipping tequila. A visit to Wahaca is a unique experience - definitely recommended (oh and they're not incredibly expensive either) Here's my review of the Qype tequila tasting evening we went to - it might give a bit more of a hint about what you might expect when you go there... londoneer.org/2011/03/te…

OPL4yvbgjwtq1VP95nflKg.text: -1 Star because of the wait to be seated and how LOUD the restaurant is. We called at 1715 for a table at 1800 and was advised that they do not take reservations. However, if you want to get your drink on in a spacious area, then waiting won't be an issue as they have a large downstairs area w/2 foosball tables, suspended seating and a large bar area; but most of the comfortable seating was "reserved." The restroom is a co-ed space so don't be confused. You will enter the same door and wash-up in the same area but the toilet areas are still separate.When seated, the paper menu was thoroughly explained to us by the staff as it looked overwhelming. There are appetizers, small dishes for sharing and large individual meals. I love these options as I like to share food and try different things. We ordered one of each. An individual burrito dish, the steak and chicken small taco meals, rice and beans, empanadas, margaritas, chips/salsa and enchiladas. The best dishes were the burrito, chicken tacos, chips/salsa, and the empanadas.The steak was dry. The margaritas were very small. The enchiladas were weird. The beans and rice were just okay.The chicken tacos were amazing! Three small tiny tortillas topped with shredded chicken, a bit of spice, some pico, and lettuce. I could have had two orders of those, by myself!The restaurant itself is an open floor plan which meant that we were yelling at each other in order to converse, which wasn't ideal, since we were there to catch-up with old friends. I wish the space had some walls to reduce the noise.The staff was friendly though and the service was fast once we ordered.  I would definitely go back again, as finding authentic mexican is hard to find in Europe. And, we came based on a recommendation from my friend that is from Mexico. She said it was the closest mexican from home that she has had since moving to Europe, and she was right. There are three Wahaca locations and next time I intend on trying the others.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

bWqZJgL54q6zXc08siB9Lg.text: I'm not a big fan of Mexican food but must give a 5-star to Wahaca! There's such a variety of menu and they are all great. My friend and I ordered multiple street food and some of them might have strong flavor (with the salsa and cilantro) but it was still so good.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The pork and chicken (something...) from the street food menu!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The chicken quesadilla

yzvodfgqxVaq_bsEvik6QA.text: Having previously never been to Wahaca I ended up frequenting the Soho location twice on my recent trip to London; on a Saturday night and a Monday lunchtime. They offer reasonably priced, good quality, street style Mexican cuisine in a colourful and vibrant setting. I wasn't expecting to eat such phenomenal Mexican on my visit, and from a chain no less.When we arrived at 6:30pm on Saturday the place was already full but we were fortunate enough to be seated right away. When we left at 9pm there was a line out the door. The server was prompt in bringing us menus, drinks, food and the bill and I felt was generally very available without being too pushy.Given that there were three of us we decided to order a suggested selection menu for 2 that included a variety of street food as well as a few supplementary items. Everything was delicious but the highlights for me were the sweet potato and feta taquitos, the guacamole and the black bean and cheese tacos (which were on a specials menu not the regular menu). My friends were big fans of the pulled pork and British skirt steak tacos. No one really had a taste for the cactus and cheese tacos but we were happy to try something different. I also ordered a hibiscus margarita which was really nice. We were fabulously full when we left.When another friend and I revisited for lunch the following Monday the place was expectedly quieter. I was impressed with how quickly they brought us the food and the bill. It was a perfect place for a quick business style lunch given that my friend had to be back in the office within the hour. I again enjoyed the sweet potato and feta taquito and hibiscus margarita (I can drink on a Monday if I'm on vacation!!) and they were just as delectable a second time.I'd definitely make a point of returning to this location or trying another one the next time I'm in the UK. There was even nightclub downstairs for those who wanted to party up with tequila shots after their meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. A selection of the selection menu

e0k4eUi2TDofURq-Fq1eYA.text: So fun! Great find! Quite a lifesaver!!Late on a London night after a show, we were starved...We happen to walk by and decided to stop. Glad we did ~ great food, great drinks and great service.We tried a variety of small plates...all were delicious. Wine was great and affordable. The staff was so accommodating we were all surprised - especially considering the time of night we arrived.Prices were fair - stop by and enjoy!!

nbPmfDUQeKdbvPgerxckjQ.text: I loved how casual this place was. You go in and plop down with your group and order from a nice selection. Food was delish, service was awesome and our orders came out REALLY fast.

hOJk8n3QBNXGdrca0KTBmw.text: Stopped in for a bite after taking in the sites. There was a bit of wait but not uncommon to me on a Friday night. Waited at the bar and had a couple of drinks. They were mostly juice, good juice but we paid for booze and it was missed. We were seated after 20 minutes and ordered tacos and a quesadilla. The pork pilbil was my favorite of the 4 dishes we tried. We also ordered the ancho chicken taco, chicken avocado taquito and a chorizo and potato quesadilla. There was nothing wrong with the other dishes, they were tasty. We frequent Mexican restaurants back home and  were missing the heat and complexity of layered flavors. Again, not bad. Just alright. Our wait staff was really friendly and super busy. He could have used some help. All in all it was a good night.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork pilbil taco, avocado chicken taquito and ancho chicken taco

8DwdtCF6VwjG3gQUMhTY4g.text: Being from Texas and having a different taste for Mexican food...this is ok. Decent black bean quesadillas. Ancho chicken tacos could have had more protein. Plenty of nice slaw radishes on top. Guac was ok. Chips need to be salted. Drinks sound fun and fancy but they use a lot of ice! The hot and fiery Arbil chili sauce was legit. Free Wifi and a fun atmosphere.  I'd stop in again esp with its close proximity to the theaters!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

gadXQ3TO-ybeUU-OTfIvYQ.text: I love this place! I've eaten at both locations and while the food was fantastic at both, I really enjoyed this colorful location more. The place is small though, so expect a pretty decent wait time to get a table.

F-9rGPMO0VXrutZOamcKZQ.text: The guacamole was great, the service was terrific, everything on the menu was reasonably priced and tasted great. Observation was tables for 2 had to wait 20 min, but our party of 5 went right in.

foTrct5mSldl75YHbf8tHA.text: Great food, ambience and value for money. Also really fresh and light food which is unlike most other Mexican restaurants. The salad was surprisingly delicious and the sweet potato and feta taquitos are a must try

iVGM4dtIj3RFAEVTbENhcA.text: I was very impressee with this mexican fusion restaurant. The guacamole honestly was not very great. We ordered a whole bunch of different stuff. TASTY!!!  Cocktails and beer too are very tasty. It all was delicious and the staff was very helpful in making selections.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

5hKnNwI4IbUY1yKAKOo67A.text: I'm going to have to say no. I have a bit of a pet peeve with intentional misspellings, so right off: Oaxaca, is spelled Oaxaca. The rest of the experience was similar, close, but inarguably wrong.Hard beans on my black bean tacos just make me mad.Watch your head on the low hanging lighting.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Watch your head on the lights!

vyqGHsT7_bd9CVAe9tIirg.text: Wahaca in Soho is a place where you might want to go for fresh, healthy and cheap food for Central London standards. We went there on a Wednesday night and almost all tables were taken so better to book in advance for a bigger group of people. They have some new interesting things on the menu, therefore I decided to give it a try and ordered a Cactus and Corn burrito that I was pretty pleased with. There is a bar downstairs, that is cute and less busy, offering some funky seating.The staff is friendly  and attentive, the food comes pretty quickly too, so well done Wahaca.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Cactus and corn burrito, new on the menu

ivevoTsexcLW1hL8Y6fOBA.text: I am a big fan of Wahaca, The plantain tacos are simply amazing. You can have a main or several street bites. 2 or 3 per person are more than enough as it is quite heavy food. You need to like spicy food though. I think is a good price for what you get.

dgZR3Nr2bQ484ev3QX8fNw.text: Nice view but the worst pork burrito I've ever had.30 grams of meat per item? Really? Be honest, just call it a rice and beans burrito in the menu.

Tv0BVuWmXDKySAEB4Lvx8Q.text: Wow-haca more like!! This place was such a brilliant find for us on a recent trip to London! The menu is extensive with an excellent selection to suit every taste. The food is really resonably priced and honestly some of the tastiest Mexican food I've ever had, with a really nice, relaxed atmosphere!We got the special of the day which was barbacoa (chilli beef) tacos with a side of sweet potato cubes and the sharing plate for two which consisted of 5 different dishes (perfect if you want to sample a few things from the menu) after starting with some guacamole and chips. Everything we had was amazing and we even went back for some more pork tacos before moving on to yummy desserts.This has been one of the best meals I've had over the past while, I honestly can't say a bad thing about the place! Go to Wahaca, eat yummy Mexican food and drink some delicious cocktails before heading to the downstairs bar and having a go on the swing! Go on, you know you want to!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Mojitos!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian tacos!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chips and guacamole!

WtP7UvVIKThl8oFZGslN1A.text: HORCHATA!!!!!!!!Nobody will every understand how ecstatic I feel whenever I'm at Wahaca because horchata horchata! Horchata aside, great fish tacos. I don't go for the little tapas style dishes because I'm not fluent in the language of food share but I imagine they taste just like their larger counterparts so order ahead if mini  food is your thing! Tortilla chips and guacamole are a must! Their coleslaw is also pretty mind shatteringly awesome.Great cocktails but this is Soho, if you have the time to spare it's a better bet to look to nearby tried and tested bars for world class cocktails. If you're short for time you can pay the bill with their mobile app. It gets busy so it's worth considering.

L8FwE0BgwnzkLlJRkfoUCQ.text: Amazing food! We ordered the Mexican feast and it was very economic considering the amount it brought and how delicious it was.The margaritas are also a must!

wbK1p_dguN9Qul32dnyttg.text: We are here on vacation from Los Angeles  and we are so sad we found this place on the last day of our trip, we would've come back many times. Our server, Noelia, was so kind and helpful and really made us feel comfortable. All of the food was seriously beyond wonderful, but the sweet potato and feta taquitos may be the best things we have ever had. I will crave this until our next visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The plantain taco was also wonderful
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

JZF02TIWrk0q6i_NpMN4kA.text: Wahaca manages to achieve the almost impossible mission of success without decline. Each branch that opens has a slightly new take on the bright Mexican street food eatery selling healthy South American tapas and the best tequila in town, all at mega affordable prices.  I have never had a bad meal or a bad margherita at Wahaca. These guys know what they're doing. Whether it's a crunchy chicken ceaser tostada, a crispy sweet potato & feta taquito or a delicious pork pibl taco, the mini dishes are a dream. Load up and enjoy! The bigger dishes are great too, whether you're into fish tacos, burritos or a salad where you can literally eat the bowl, it's all great! Make sure you start off with THE best guacamole and chips, and end with the decadent churros with chocolate sauce to complete your Wahaca experience. And don't forget the tequila! This location is slightly larger than others, with a side bar and the chance to have a boogie!

m8VvnR2JVUYb4H_t95U0DA.text: The drinks were great, food was good. This is almost nothing like actual Mexican food but is a yummy alternative to the disgusting traditional British food. Ask how spicy your dish is, you may be surprised!

9yAEIvVMzBvC4lV0r8FRXg.text: Defently not like the best Mexican places in NY or SF, but consider this is a chain from UK. I think the food and place is nice, god service and trendy spot to visit in Soho. The margaritas was very small though(bad!) Prices are reasonable.

8TbxOr4ukKkbyZKcyl80KQ.text: I visited Wahaca as part of a Qype event  we were invited to try a selection of their drinks and nibbles in their downstairs bar area, while also enjoying a preview of episode 2 of owner Thomasina Miers' new TV series, Mexican Food Made Simple. I'm ashamed to say that despite hearing many good things about them, I have never been in a branch of Wahaca before  more fool me. The Soho branch had a lovely rustic feel to it, and the downstairs bar was nice and cosy, with a variety of chairs (including some hanging basket seats that I wasn't brave enough to try sitting in). The staff were all wonderful to us - all happy to chat, recommend drinks, and lots of smiles - when people enjoy their jobs it really shows in the customer experience! I considered it my duty to try a number of the tequila cocktails: Mayan Gold  delicious and cinnamon-y; Passionfruit margarita nice and fruity; The Barragon which was a lovely refreshing grapefruit & lemonade concoction; and my favourite the deliciously crisp apple mojito  yum (can I have another?) And then the food. Oh wow! We were offered the following: broad bean & feta quesadillas  so creamy and perfect for sopping up alcohol; the black bean tostadas which exploded with flavour in my mouth; and saving the best for last, the pork pibil taco, which was everything is should be  juicy (or as I told my husband when I spilled some on my dress, leaky), spicy but absolutely full of flavour  if I have to go back for anything, it will be more of these. A lot more!

IcepWCS4mMxO7zJnlvTF9w.text: Superb Mexican street food.  We arrived at about 2:30 PM, so we were seated immediately.  We ordered pork tacos and sweet potatoes, and my youngest daughter got a kids meal.  All of the food was wonderful.   Our server was not very attentive, but the delicious food and the fact that were not in a hurry made up for that.  We sat outside overlooking the Snog Frozen Yogurt bus and the Thames.  I wish that we would have found wahaca earlier in our trip!

_GZ7znkXKeojVUdXv5BoVQ.text: Very rude staff!!!!!!!! They hung up on me TWICE when I asked about reservations instead of just yelling me they don't take reservations. No more of my business OR any of my friends.

SarSBf2pcTLEsK2g66Lbtg.text: This place kind of surprised me but let me point out my 4 star review for a London Mexican restaurant translates to about a 3 back in the States. The chips and salsa were nothing to write home about but the cochinita pibil and chicken tinga tacos were pretty good, this is what surprised me. If you ever crave tacos is London check this place out.

eDSYLMDJCewkpbJ7M06AyA.text: Me and my girlfriend spent here some time during lunch and I have to say the restaurant is awesome and good looking. We had some tacos, nachos and their own lemonade and all of those were really tasty. I would definitely recommend you this place. Go there!

gZrCa8LEtApOoD7S6pRlZQ.text: Was decent. The food was OK. But the prices were very high in correspondence to the portion sizes. The restaurant was really cool though.

_A9Pb1gH2sska9MRVTxqUw.text: Cheap, quick, tasty!!! Delicious place, were service is always very good and fresh, staff is friendly.Usually take the street food selection to share, with some Guacamole, and that is just the best thing!Salads are also very generous and taste amazing.A place I am taking people to when we go central and want something affordable and exotic!Always very busy...Can not disappoint!

YrVP19kgf8rN3IkoItwTdg.text: I'm torn on this place. I've been twice and both times the food was pretty good, but there's always something that prevents me from categorizing it as a 4 star place.I went today, we were a group of 5. We ordered guacamole to share and it was just OK - not sure how to make guac so flavorless but they managed. I also ordered the special of barbacoa tacos, which are 3 pretty small tacos with sopping wet meat. it was tasty, but really really salty (and i add extra salt to EVERYTHING). i had to eat it with the very bland guac to neutralize it. the chicken tostadas were actually pretty tasty. no complaints here - piled pretty high with ingredients and the flavors fit together well. it was like eating a salad more than anything since the tortilla was so tiny and thin. the side of frijoles - black beans with some cotija cheese and cream - was very good! very creamy. will be getting these again. Don't get the Mexican Hot Chocolate. It's dairy free because it's made with water and I felt like it was grainy, rich, but watered down nonetheless. I got the horchata last time I came and it was so so watery. blegh!It's a great place for groups to gather which is kind of rare in Soho, and there's plenty of options for everyone. I think it's probably a good place for people who haven't really had Mexican food. My Dutch friends absolutely loved it. I still miss my taco trucks in LA, and this doesn't really hit the spot. But it's fine.

HeCztHF-0lMXQWofvFdUbw.text: I was told to meet at the Mexican restaurant on Wardour, but when I stepped in, the fleeting glimpse of square white plates and the general ambiance gave me the immediate impression of it as Asian, so I stepped out and ran up and down the street a few times before slinking back.  Maybe I'm just an idiot, though, 'cause as as soon as I was seated and food started pouring down on us, it was definately Mexican, and how.  The food was really tasty, plenty of stinging pepper and spice with perfectly cooked beans and meat in a crisped tortilla shell for the most interesting burrito I've had in the area (it certainly felt traditional, but my fondness for the hole-in-the-wall kind precludes it from being the best), and my soothing horchata quelched the fire inside.  The tortillas were freshly fried and crisp, and I even liked the guacamole, which is something as I'm typically not a fan. Service was prompt, attentive, and sassy, and prices surprisngly reasonable for the upscale vibe.  Well done, Wahaca.  Now that I think of it, how could I possibly have thought it was Asian, when the very name sounds like you just bludgeoned a rattlesnake on a cactus plant with a machete on a hot desert day? Doesn't it?

bNYJzH1JwL1eOu5GljmRCg.text: Coming from San Francisco I warned myself not to set high expectations for a Mexican joint so far away. However I was excited to see a large variety and most of the meats I'm used to in this popular area of central London. They do some really interesting things, such as the Herron Tostada meal, and the burritos made with Indian-type (long grain) rice.The guacamole is tasty and the other sauces are spicy and fresh, including the chicken mole. The drinks are great too and a large menu is offered to accompany your meal. Maybe some of the dishes are quite small, but the explosive taste compensates for this slight issue.This place is the bomb. Don't say that in London though, you might get in trouble.

GiVb-V4vF_903a7baq_lPw.text: This place is super cute. I get hungry just thinking about it. The price is really reasonable considering just how good the food is!!!

dtvMaiF52pzx-Agi7H3_Wg.text: Favourite restaurant in London! The food is fantastic with a great selection of dishes to suit everyone. You can either go down the "tapas-style" route and order a few small dishes to share or go through a large main dish. I prefer ordering a few smaller dishes, means you get to try a little of everything!I recommend the broad bean and geta quesadilla and frijoles! And ofcourse, for a drink, a margerita!The staff are also really friendly, despite there being a long queue they always are very polite and helpful. The setting of the southbank is also great!

_d78BIGxf4bp5QgzDuz-7g.text: Just tried this restaurant out. The food is great, and the atmosphere was really hopping. We were told there would be a 30-minute wait for two on a Friday night, but we got in really fast. Even if you have to wait, it's not a big deal, since there's a lovely bar downstairs.I had the veggie burrito, which tasted lovely. To be fair, though, the food has almost nothing to do with Oaxaca, the Mexican state. It's fresh, good food that gestures toward Mexican food.Wahaca is also a great deal. I'd go again.

qfJ_k3hNIDnh6gohu5owJA.text: I ate here when it opened last summer.I was with a group of friends and we've had been wanting to try Wahaca for a while based on the good reviews from our peers.We all ordered mojito df's to start with. We said cheers and sipped them at the same time.The look on everybody's face was the same as was the general consensus. The mojitos were all terribly weak. I doubt if they even had 5ml of alcohol in them. Honestly they were the weakest mojitos I've ever had. We complained to the waiter and he assured us that they were made properly. Apparently our tableful of customers were wrong :/The food them came and it was disappointingly sub par. Everyone's meat was ridiculously overcooked.When I asked the waiter for some water for the table I was told that 'we don't serve water'.I've never had that happen before.We left extremely disappointed and extremely hungry as no-one could finish the badly made food.Other people still tell me that Wahaca is amazing, so I'm hoping that the staff as this particular branch were just useless.

0WH6QYNMboCN9swUpy_kCw.text: The Qype event here was the first time I had been to the Soho branch of Wahaca, having already been to the Westfield and Canary Wharf versions.It was good to see the fairly sizeable bar, well stocked with sipping tequila of course, taken as cocktails they were rather good, and funnily enough the promise of no hangover was pretty accurate... We were there to see an episode of co-owner Thomasina Miers Mexican cooking show which is on Channel 5 at the moment and once we did that it was time for a few nibbles which were tasty as always.I've just made the salsa on the show and it's delicious. Hard to judge the restaurant on what we were given and on the bar area alone but with swing seats and a spinning top to sit on, there was fun to be had in there for sure...!

XDR_wdA5G9HDKXTlbzrS7w.text: finally made it here for dinner with a group of friends. my boyfriend and i ordered the sweet potatoes and guac to share - both were delicious and size wise, although not big, was just right. i also had the ceviche salad which came in a burrito bowl. it was delicious and really spicy. i don't know if it was already spicy cos i added some of the hot sauce on the table before i tasted it haha, but it was soooooo good. i think i would have preferred it if the shrimp was a bit bigger and more substantial than it was but it was so filling and really reasonably priced. other orders around the table included beef burritos, fish tacos and quesadillas - everyone was happy with their food. my friend liked his fish tacos he said he wished he could never stop eating them!i also had a tamarind margarita which was just delightful. i love margaritas so much. i actually think the margaritas here are reasonably priced for a central london eaterie and have no problem paying the £5.95 for them. the wine list is also reasonably priced.

5Nd574PvwmP7fEUlou_N9w.text: Reasonably priced Mexican food with a little spice!  We ordered the chips and guacamole, steak tacos, crab and avocado tostadas, chicken quesadilla, and churros.  All were delicious

IXHEx70WgvLH2BG5ZhF34Q.text: As much as I want to give Wahaca 5 stars, I just can't. The food is great, and apart from my recent chicken burrito which they admit still isn't quite right, I've never eaten badly there, and it's got a great atmosphere and nice decor. The problem is I think it's let down by the service. The time before last, the waitress was really pushy, trying to get us to order lots of side dishes and cocktails and such. She kept coming back and asking and it was quite annoying.Last time it was the opposite. The waitress was a bit inattentive and it took ages for her to come and ask if we were ok because we'd said we were waiting for some people. They did arrive and when it came to pay it took ages to get her attention to ask for the bill. I love the place otherwise, so it'd be 5 star if it wasn't for the service.

19_LP99ZV31pxEMiFdkcow.text: Delicious, fresh, flavorful Mexican. Drinks are wonderful and creative. (I think we had a drink for every taco haha). The pork pibil and fish tacos were great as were the tostadas and super fresh guac. We're from America where yummy Mexican offerings are on almost every corner and I wasn't disappointed.  The service was friendly and the space is bright and fun. We came for late lunch and had a great experience.

A3lhbDzKA0-tWNrGsMaOqQ.text: I remember the days when Southbank was a cultural gem and culinary wasteland. Now it has a good selection of both and Wahaca has become one of my faves. It is particularly great in summer as they have some outdoor seating overlooking the Thames.It was pouring down with rain on my last visit and you are more aware of sitting ina shipping container then. Still, the lovely Mexican food helps take away the chill - and no queues either.The concept is easy, you order a number of small plates to share and they arrive as and when the kitchen makes a new batch. Perfect for those who prefer a variety of tastes rather than a massive portion of just one dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

3q4f92CbDrXSVS2zjF4Wgw.text: Wahaca was a surprising choice for us tourists from California. Judging by Wahaca I would skip Mexican food in London in the future (which perhaps isn't fair to generalize a whole city but tough titties, London).The good: we had a nice view...The steak taco had way too much cabbage. The cabbage was marked a lack of authenticity to me. (I only ever see that on fish tacos. The rest of the time it's romaine all the way.) I had the sweet potato and feta taquito (yes, I know inauthentic - but the flavors sounded good). I liked the taquito itself but there was too much sauce drizzled on the plate. The feta of the taquito was on the shredded lettuce on the side, which was disappointing. I thought it would be inside the taquito. It was good overall but not great.My chorizo and potato quesadilla was the lowest point of the meal. The chorizo flavor was a little off for me. Plus, they added chorizo oil to it so the whole thing was a dripping red mess.The kids had the quesadilla kids' meals, which came with veggies and hibiscus aqua frescas. I was pleased that aqua frescas made it across the pond.

x-BdHNPPJ9mO2PlBl2KQqA.text: Chain of mexican food with branches all over London. Nice food and prices but its more of another fast food chain with nothing exceptional to think about.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

878NFXa-ffdYF2YxWDtnNA.text: Rude service and mediocre Mexican food. The ordering procedure was hard to understand at first and the waiter wasn't even polite when he rudely explained it to us. We all started with one course, I got chicken tacos and my friends got black bean quesadillas. The tacos were too spicy. Not great flavor at all. The quesadillas could've had more flavor and were bland tasting. We also ordered some guacamole and that was eh as well. At one point I was trying to get our waiters attention and he looked at me and rudely said "give me one minute!" Remember, I'm paying you?! It was annoying and I'll never be back. A waste of my time.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tacos

C9nGt7V-dCULHQQn3IsRsw.text: +++- Chicken burrito can fill 2-3 people++- Can't beat the service- The margarita is a creeper- British steak is dope- As is the grilled chicken and avocado+- Plantain taco is A+- While tasty, The pork pibil left more to be desired

wjXB0AiwcNwEebDoVYqkoQ.text: This location in particular is massive and has plenty of space. Our waiter was surprisingly cool headed despite our group being pretty-asshole-y. I'll admit it and I'm sorry. A few people didn't want to eat anything and no one really acknowledged him when he came over. People couldn't make up their minds, everyone wanted to pay separately.. you get it. But I tried to be nice, because I'm nice. Anyway, food was really great, and I like that they circle what you get on your menu so there's no confusion. I had the cactus tacos which were surprisingly delicious, as were the sweet potato fries. Well done Wahaca, well done.
