Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Cactus tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Rise and beans side with meat from a taco

FBb_yuyxFzwDTCTMUnKLEw.text: Huge place, but yet they manage to keep the service friendly and efficient. Food was delicious too. Would be back!

0LWDiZyWKiFrisxnJ_y9Rw.text: Soho is quite an cultural area of London to visit.  Their Mexican food was quite superb!  The services were great. The prices were reasonable.  You must go to this place for their flavorful and creative food.  Their Margaritas were quite delicious.  It is one of my favorite places to go.

B81hXoDl5Jg3DCVOjc2ZSg.text: Just meh. Boring food. Terrible service. It feels like a chain and it acts like one. I would not recommend it to anyone.

jG-HHT3_2-AnsLWo2LSf3A.text: A tamed down version of true Mexican food. I'm usually suspicious of Mexican restaurants that are so geographically far from Latin America, however I was pleasantly surprised by Wahaca. The food is your basic UK version of "Mexican fare" including margaritas, quesadillas, and guac but it isn't as bad as I thought. Although food lacks spice or authenticity it is a good option for people who looking for a classic "queso and margaritas" kind of Mexican brunch food. If your looking for traditional Latin food this is not the place. But if your looking for a trendy take on Latin, like pomegranate margaritas, with a fun atmosphere then it may be the place for you. As a bonus, the restaurant gives complimentary chile pepper seed to plant in your own garden!

-qO7WofLFRzdupd6xXvoRg.text: I learned that this is a chain, but I am still a fan. I have to admit that I just randomly popped inside this one in Soho due to the good looking entrance. I loved the colours and the quirky drawings on the wall and was drawn in.Inside I saw that it was a fun place with lots of different seating options etc. Since I was dining alone I sat by the window. Which was a great idea - way to deal with my curios side and also to charge my phone (when a tourist with a phone as the only means, you can run out of battery).The waiter (Jorge) came quickly and took my drink order. I had to try the vanilla and passion fruit mohito., Yummy! And of course I had to have a beer as well. Both came quickly. As for food, I decided to go for the pork pibil. Pork in tortilla with some spicy red onions. Even though it was a little bit messy, it had a good deal of flavor to it. Ok priced, loved the decor, food and drinks tasted good and service was good and quick! Bonus for extra chili seeds to grow at home.Absolutely I place I would visit again for some drinks and some tacos!:)

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Bar downstairs.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Grow chilis when you get home!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

uJ08fI9erQhYLEuRr33oqw.text: Had lunch with my mini-me at Wahaca today, mostly because we needed a guacamole fix (we were in LA for far too many years). Here are my thoughts:Service is very friendly but our waiter clearly had too many tables and was running around, so we waited a LONG time for him to take our order. Unfortunately we finally had to flag down another server to take our order, who was happy enough to assist.Food is overall pretty good. Guacamole is tasty, prawn tacos were good, steak tacos were a bit chewy (according to mini-me), vegetarian tostada was good, rice and beans was so good we ordered a second and demolished that one too.Prices were reasonable for London.The bottom line: Wahaca can't hold a candle to Mexican food in LA but it's definitely good by London standards. We'll return I'm sure.

kJCJLd8hOytxflutDpVA0Q.text: We tried a lot of dishes most of them from the starters and all of them were really tasty and different. They do amazing sweet potato tacos which are a must try!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

N2KWvDJ_xmz1yzs7ktCgFA.text: I met here with a friend for a long catch up chat. We shared one of their taster menues and it was great! So much variety in one meal, it's great. The only thing I really don't understand is why a sharing menu for two serves several dishes in threes. Wouldn't a number divisible by 2 make more sense? The staff are quite good, if a little slow at times. Seating is nice but it does get quite loud and busy at times.Overall I'd recommend it but it does have potential for improvement!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. So much awesome food!

Uzx62vx29ZMmWshNRM_0_w.text: I loved this restaurant! I decided to come here for the first time with my boyfriend, as he loves Mexican food. Firstly, the staff was super nice and helpful. The space inside the restaurant is very creative and engaging, and I loved it. I was scared that because it was a Mexican restaurant, I wouldn't be able to find any healthy options, but I was happily surprised to find out that their salads are also super healthy and taste amazing and spicy! My boyfriend also loved the quesadillas, and overall it was a great night out.

P-TskxGdtxa2LKVkyx0Gbg.text: This location has a great vibe and fun atmosphere. Walk to the back bar if you want a quick drink or are waiting for a table. There is a full cocktail menu and lots of Mexican beer on the list.Wait staff were friendly and explained the menu as I was a first timer. With a large food menu there are several smaller bites to share or larger options as well. Our table got a good mix of tacos, my favorite being the fried cod loaded with veggies and a slightly spicy crema. The crispy prawns tacos were even more caliente. Their take on bbq wings were delicious and the pork tacos had a nice flavour. Even their simple chips and frijoles were yummy with melted cheese.Reasonable prices and flavourful dishes hit the mark. This lively spot is both casual and fun with friends.

mLC54M0ndkkw90YlL7HTAw.text: The location is pretty nice right off the water. My friend and I weren't seated where we could have a view but it was too hot to sit outside in the sun, so that's okay. The vibe is cool and they have a good locationLucky for me it was Tuesday and they have 1 pound tacos for each person for your first order of tacos. My friend didn't want tacos so the two orders of tacos for me were only a pound each! I got their signature pork tacos and plantain tacos. The pork tacos were nothing to write home about (hence the loss of one star) but the plaintain tacos were awesome. I'm from California so I know Mexican food. And I'm also a sucker for plantains. Personally I wish that I had gotten two orders of the plantain tacos instead, but I'll know for next time. The tacos were on the small side though so I probably wouldn't order it if it hadn't been only a pound - I'm a burrito type of girl anyway

q9YhkejeuHhzW8a4SsZXkA.text: Great food, great ambience, employees very friendly.  One of the few places opened late and close to the hotel. Food had a lot of flavor. Best was the barbacoa tacos. I am very picky with the aguas frescas and they're Jamaica was amazing! Very impressed.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chips and guacamole

iccPhqZ7hKMOQ-BquatUHA.text: Wow the food...  I still dream about the sweet potato I had.  It tasted fantasticly! The place is super busy and so are the waiters.  They should slow down a bit but I can see why they are so stressed. The nibbles guacamole and nachos was boring but oh that sweet potato feta and pea and mint empanada: smashing I tell you.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Bar

zy13szy0zOD_3NM_M6SP2A.text: You might have met this restaurant before. In Covent Garden you might have encountered the younger, energetic, slightly slutty (literally people queueing round the block to give her a try) Prom Queen version of Wahaca. We all had fun back in those halcyon days right?Well now meet the sexier, mature, grown-up girl that knows who she is, what she wants and what she can offer you. There's no messing now. Wahaca has learnt from her youthful experimental days and now offers you a polished experience.The big bar downstairs is a better as a place to grab a drink before your meal (and the inevitable wait for your table) and even somewhere to come if you're not eating. The layout is better. The staff have grasped what great customer service really is.All in all, the best of the Wahaca options. And the food? Delicious as always.

KBw1TJcdi0Y0nLT7DtQGoQ.text: OMG! This place is my new favourite!  Everything we had was boom most striking the pork pibil wow with a refreshing wahaca margarita Hibiscus and I was left with a smile of chillaxed mood. Happy stomach and tipsy mind.

vTqIt_Tlj56ttaNl9IP4PQ.text: Very delicious. Best Mexican food I ever had, and best London restaurant we've visited (granted, there were only two. But still).

8avTeF9qKHQ5Aaemxw_d7g.text: This place is phenomenal! Carlos, our Canadian waiter, helped us pick out some amazing dishes. We opten for the "street food" on the menu and weren's disappointed. We are a couple of vegetarians, which was great because there were tons and tons of options. Being from the states, we are very familiar with Mexican food. I must say, Wahaca did not disappoint. The veggie tacos and taquitos were out-of-this-world. Carlos highly recommended the side of sweet potatoes. They were hands down the best thing I've ever eaten. He said that the employees were too addicted, so they're not allowed to eat them anymore.Go. Get a margarita. Order a side of sweet potatoes. Ask for Carlos. You'll thank me.

tyg3L9yIurjL8PCwzH6Udg.text: Having largely grown up in a Mexican neighborhood in my hometown of LA, I'd say Wahaca does a good job delivering (high street) Mexican fare.The beef burrito isn't skimpy on the beef and you even have a choice between pinto or black beans.  Extra points for that.The fish tacos were acceptable, except that the tortilla got a bit too soggy if left too long to sit.  I blame the freshly diced tomatoes.

dQ9DTt1F_UABeyCpmIif-A.text: The vibe on of this small restaurant along the Thames is casual yet trendy. Its a great place to come with friends for a tapas-like experience of tasting many dishes and sharing across the table. Try the Chicken Taquitos and the Chorizo & Potato Quesadilla. For a bit of a larger plate, try the Slow-cooked Pork Burrito with a dab of the habanero salsa that is bottled on the table if you like a strong spice! Make sure to try their many flavors of margaritas with your meal, especially the Passion Fruit Margarita, which is divine! Drink it slowly though! It tastes so sweet and fruity you could forget that there is alcohol in it.

M8wxQqWdQn_whRVW2PEF4A.text: I love this place and have only ever taken one friend who did not like it, but she's not a fan of spicy food... The Bloody Maria is sublime, the pork Pibil is just fabulous, as at the fish tacos and all the street food.. They do a tequila tasting which I must try. It's far superior to the Covent Garden one as is much larger and the bar downstairs is great.I love the ethos too - local produce and carbon and waste neutral.. Well done Tomasina!

pTUh67P_ohEEAJ6EA01i1Q.text: I had yet to go to this branch because there is always an hour wait when I have showed up and quite frankly, there are better restaurants in Soho.  However last night a shorter wait and a craving for Mexican and its atmosphere broke the spell.  The space is absolutely amazing--great architectural touches and decor--loved just being in the vibrant space.  We went for the sharing platter for two, and had plenty of food for 10 quid each, so I was feeling really happy about the deal.  We also thoroughly enjoyed the dulce de leche ice cream with Valhrona chocolate chunks.  Yummy!Server was really charming--always appreciated.  I think the food here is innovative--a bit higher end than the burrito places and a bit edgy....not as good as true Mexican, but a decent stand-in whilst in London.

4J7TPHKg27ePGJ6H2wJo7Q.text: No, this is not the way to introduce Londoners (or anyone, who hasn't lived in America) to Mexican food. Do it the American way. Get them to eat Taco Bell, hangover quesadillas and then gourmet up a cuisine which has had some marinade-time with the local palette. After living in London for over four years I am still not convinced that this is a popular cuisine. And Mexican food is certainly not top of the mind comfort food, so I have observed. While Wahaca does not do a bad job at the food, it doesn't do justice to the presentation. The restaurant has a distinctly different feel when you compare it to an average or above average Mexican restaurant in the US (I haven't been to Mexico). If I didn't know better I would have thought that this was a fancy American diner.The food is well portioned and there's little chance that you will go home hungry. The flavours are not super authentic and there seems to be a deliberate attempt at a hint of affected fusion. I'll go back but this is not one I will think of if I have to recommend Mexican food.

qtfGFgzt-GtzJDusRHlKXw.text: Nice to eat in some old sea containers! Menu is cut down version of main restaurants, but not too bad. Staff fast and attentive.

-yVteJOdLZhZPwyy8s6vkg.text: Friendly food in a tin box.I love the South Bank and always have done since I was a teenager. I love the pure brutalist architecture as do many other poncey middle class north Londoners. So that's me covered. So some garishly painted sea containers plonked on one of Londons finest examples of brutalist architecture meant I was pissed off and not going to take part in their tex mex reinvented offering. However hunger and a few days holiday relaxed my cranky views and with my tolerant wife we entered the Wahaca tin boxes.Service, at 12.20, was quick friendly and helpful. Seated upstairs the view and interior on a sunny day felt quite nice. It was all quite nice. The food, a selection of sharing dishes, were all three yelp stars OK. I'm no Mexican food expert but I just found Wacacha's offerings a little bland. I love chilli but not when you have to add it yourself from an own brand - available in a supermarket near you - bottle of chilli sauce with overpowering notes of vinegar. It's like a old fashioned cafe where you smother the food in cheap tomato sauce to give it flavour. Finally we went for a little dessert. We customised their vanilla ice cream with nuts and caramel topping to peanut butter ice cream with the toppings. The mean three scoops arrived with nuts but no caramel. The ice cream had formed large crystals, the ultimate ice cream sin. Service was very good and I tipped suitably. Other people love it.

wXf6zwCQj1dUrM_Q2-0YqA.text: This is the best Wahaca I've visited in London and as good as it gets when it comes to Mexican dining in London all things considered. The staff are very friendly and helpful and the downstairs bar is a great place to have a couple of pre-dinner drinks if you have to wait for a table. You really cannot go wrong with their food selection. I prefer to share a number of the smaller dishes instead of having one large dish. The menus and specials change regularly but I can recommend at least one Modelo beer 'Michelada', the Frijoles to start and the Quesadillas are particularly good. Fresh, simple food that's well presented in a fantastic atmosphere!

CFDV8Il1pFP19Q_mQD5iBg.text: Great service and unique "Anglo-Mex" eats. Loved the portions on the shared plates, and my wife's burrito was a generous one. Our server was on her game, and it was a fluid, delicious meals. Will return for sure the next time we are in the UK.

0mUq1pFNTNdJ349gcXde9g.text: This place is staggering!I'm not an expert in Mexican food but found this place really interesting while visiting London last time. In the heart of Soho there is inconspicuous from outside but admirable from inside restaurant. It's always full of people but the friendly staff will surely find you a table.The idea of this place is to taste a couple of mexican dishes instead of getting a full one. Personally I've tried a pork bill tacos, chicken quajillo tostadas and chipotle chicken quesadillas. The first one i can higly recommend. Remind that most of the dishes are very spicey so they give you a free water which is reasonable and quite nice.It's pricey  to taste a mexican food here, especially because the portions aren't very big, but for sure you won't regret.

aJevQlzoiWKzTALNX3IiFg.text: When you say "Mexican" and "tapas" to me in the same sentence, I'm so happy I can barely speak. I also can't speak because I'm probably eating. Queue up because this place is positively worth the wait. You can also keep your hands busy with their strong and good margaritas while you wait. This place is fresh, vibrant, and fun. The standouts were the chorizo and potato quesadilla (delightfully smoky) and the pork pibil tacos (so scrumptious). They give you a large amount of food for little plates and appetizers. We were stuffed to the gills, but I kept eating. We were not fans of the queso fundido. I, the adventurous one, ate the cactus it came with and was not impressed. It tasted like a salty stalk of boiled broccoli. I'm sure cactus could be good if they doctored it up a bit. I also liked the ferociously spicy trio of sauces the chips came with. Very fun place. Hit it up if you're jonesing for some Mexican in Britishland.

HMwLvaJBQOmHoABMDcsF8Q.text: Yum! I haven't lived in England for a while now, so I was super excited to have some good Mexican food in London (the north is shit for anything other than Indian or chippies) The service and food was good. Portions are small (tacos are half the size of the ones I got in Cabo Wabo) but quality was high. I recommend the fish entree too, and I really liked the pork tacos, so juicy!

mJ5gbydZh6XNX-1g77bMtA.text: Food very good, fresh, organic, locally sourced etc... Loved my burrito and the dessert was passable but not great. Decor is fine... but not warm or inviting. Seems a little like they are trying too hard to look like a little local cafe in Mexico... but nothing wrong with it. Seemed very clean, and committed to both tasteful and quality food. Only real downside, service poor... really poor. Over the course of an hour prob saw our server twice and two wrong orders (food item was right... but no avocado turned into no anything on 2 of the 4 burritos... huh?).I would go back... food would rank 4 stars but the service knocked it down a star. Make it a little warmer and more comfortable... even better. If you go, pass on the dessert and go to the high-end chocolate place in covenant gardens (don't recall name) and get the chocolate Gelato that was out of this world good.

OI7youN5p9wUIWep15XTiA.text: Excellente! My friend and I were craving chips & salsa and margaritas. When we arrived, the place was packed, which is usually a good sign. We had an hour wait for a table, so they sent us downstairs to the bar area. Seating was a bit tight down there as well, but we were able to share a table with some people and we sampled a couple different margaritas. I started out with the Tamarind Margarita, which was really good, but I slurped it down in 3 sips, they put A LOT of ice in the small glass, £5.95 each, you can easily rack up a large bill! They also serve chips, salsa and guac downstairs while you're waiting for your table. After a couple rounds we were starving and headed upstairs, our waitress was very attentive and gave a couple recomendations for us, we ordered the Pork Pibil, Plaintain Tacos and the MSC fish a la Pimienta (we chose fried, not grilled fish). Everything was delicious, but the standout was the Michelada. It was like liquid gold, you have to try this if you like spicy cocktails. Don't come if you're in a hurry, this place was worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Plaintain tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pulled Pork Tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Fish tacos

aMXHQoje03YessydYo8r5Q.text: Having an American for a sister in law means that any Mexican food has to be top notch. So when she said she had found a Mexican place that meets her very high standards I knew we were in for a treat.The food was so tasty, although I got food envy and as my husbands quesadilla was easily the best thing on the table. The pork was delicious. The cocktails were excellent and the choice of Tequilla made the dinner. Unlike some places in Soho the service was brilliant and we will be going back again,

6G_ahORJJzm8OTq4JOW_7Q.text: I came back to the US raving and raving about this place and yea, I'm only going to give it 3 stars. I mean, relative to the rest of the food in London and the surrounding areas, Wahaca was a five star joint, relative to the heavy greasy pub food. Nothing here was slathered in sauce and deep fried to death. This restaurant saved my Paleo life. The food served here is locally sustained (at least that is what their menu says) and it was pretty good! I have to say I am in love with their unique pairing of scratchings (fluffy pork rinds) and guacamole. Love. I mean, I could eat that combo all freakin day. I never thought to put the two together! Wahaca, in American terms is like if Whole foods owned Chevy's. It's mostly healthy and they were able to alter the menu for me and food is locally grown. No SF style large mouth watering burritos here but the British steak taco's are not bad at all.Yea. I went here 3 times during my stay in the UK. They are a chain restaurant and I'm OK with that. I do love the "after meal" treats they give. They are ancho chili seeds in a matchbook. How awesome!

--Nr_L8RqK9M0R5wKd_GRg.text: No clue how I found about this place, it I'm happy I did :-)I agree, you have to be patient to get a place... During the evening general 1 hour waiting before a table frees up. No reservation possible :-(But a well stocked bar serving nice margaritas facilitates the waiting :-) (also some beers where you choose the spices that go with it... Discovered that yesterday, did not know about it before... Pretty nice actually :-) )For the food: mainly lots of small patters to share, which are simply delicious. Nice choice, better than the typical Mexican restaurant. So very happy of the choice, great to go with some friends.As for the staff: friendly and helpful, once you got your table, ordering is quick and food gets there quickly too :-)

Z_ggoFc-080E5DxHhyE7pQ.text: Since moving from Manchester I have been rather grumpy about my eating out options. For the most part, my experience had been defined by bad service, expensive dishes and waiters keen to give you the bill as soon as you have sat down. I missed my old favourites and nothing could be found to rival them. At least until I discovered Wahaca. Admittedly I was rather keen to try Thomasina Miers' restaurants. I have the cookbooks at home and having made a few of the dishes myself they have always been pleasantly received. What sets this style of Mexican apart is the wondrous amount of Fresh ingredients used. It's a world away from Old Del Passo/ chiquittos, where at best you may find a soggy red pepper hidden in layers of cheese.Okay, it's no reservations, but as this is London on a Friday night there is about a 1 hour wait to get a table. Luckily the bar is fantastic. We decided that it was somewhere we would go even if we weren't being made to wait there. The cocktails were divine, as sugary alcohol-y cocktails always are. I sampled a Paloma which was wonderfully fruity and light. The boyfriend, ever the adventurer, had his standard Corona which apparently was "very competitively priced for London"; a very big compliment indeed.The service is snappy. You are warned that all your dishes will arrive at different times so best to get a bit of everything. All of the street food dishes are around 4 pounds each, but there are also bigger dishes prices at around 8 pounds, great for a solo lunch. Some of our favorites were the Chorizo and potato Quesadillas, the chorizo had a great flavour and not too heavy considering what they contained. Classic pork pil pil tacos were updated with a lovely onion relish. We hadn't tried taquitos before, but of course anything with a description that includes the words 'deep fried' has to be tried. This is where you begin to be glad the portions are small.All in all Wahaca is a perfect example of Mexican street food at its best. I think this would be the perfect place for a first date; it's loud, trendy, the food is crying out to be shared, and if things aren't going so well the speedy table service means you can always make a quick exit...

oLP-YrKmDyg3wmHTWavZxw.text: Coming from California I thought it might be fun to check out a Mexican place. Food was really good, kind of a tapas menu except Mexican food instead of Spanish. They have larger plates too, but we tried the "street food"Chicken tinga were ok, I'd rather cubed Asada style than shreddedChorizo & potato quesadilla 10/10 they were greatChorizo empanadas (special) good stuff and 20p is donated to charity :OFun atmosphere with the cantina downstairs  and the restaurant above. Open late too

wtvUigXYS5P6_cKnD8qDKA.text: I had been wanting to come here for a while now, as I had heard a lot about this restaurant opened by Masterchef winner Thomasina Miers located in the heart of Soho.Two things stood out for me when deciding on a girls night out here, the fact that the menu is based on Mexican Street Food and downstairs is a Tequila Bar!Although we went on a Saturday evening, we were told if we arrived before 6.30 we wouldn't need a reservation. On arrival we were met by the friendliest and rather flirty staff, who were quite happy for us to head downstairs to sample a few of the tequila based cocktails first and develop an appetite before ordering any food which we did about an hour later. So, when we tipsily heading back to the dining area at 7.30 although the place was heaving, we were immediately shown to a table, perfect!The menu's are printed on the placemats, and with so much too chose from, you can have a whole range of dishes, a bit like Tapas, with Tortillas, Tacos, Enchiladas, Tamales and a whole range of rices, guacamoles and tortas. We all went for the sharing plates, and for £20 for two, there was more than enough to satisfy us.  Oh, and leave room for Thomasina's Cheesecake with Hibiscus, one of the best cheesecakes ive ever eaten!But back to the Tequila bar . .  and we most definitely did return here after our meal. Set out like a Mexican square, the bar in located in the corner with very knowledgable staff in all things related to the Agave plant.  Great seating, including chairs swinging from the ceiling and who can resist that after a Tequila Sour or two, and a couple of fuss-ball tables for those still able to stand. Snacks are also available down in the bar, so plates of guacamole and tortillas were always making their way round.All that and everyone leaves with a small packet of Chili seeds to grown at home, whats not to love!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. want nacho's with your tequila?

NeDnN7nuxElyZgH1JaTrdA.text: I've been to a Wahaca once a few years ago and wasn't incredibly impressed by it. Finally years later I went again and I enjoyed it much more! We had to wait to be seated on a Monday evening but it was only about 10 minutes, and we were able to get a drink at the bar while we waited. The drinks are fantastic, quite strong, and they're a good price, so even if you're not into the food, you'll want to go for the tequila cocktails.The majority of the food that I had was really good. There are definitely those things that stand out, like the pork pibil tacos and the plantain tacos (though can't they have some fried plantain as a side? PLEASE?), and those that are just okay, like the black bean quesadillas. It's definitely a good idea to share with friends so that you get a good range of choices, since it can be hit and miss. We had great service, quick but friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is great, and so relaxed, which is how I like it. My Texan friend with a Mexican partner said while it wasn't as good as home, it was still very good, so it's a solid choice for Mexican in London.

o8rhB6PMgsWwr3d3kRKC7Q.text: I'm pretty skeptical about any ethnic food coming out of the UK besides Indian food or kebabs... but after a few friends from Mexico told me this place "isn't bad", I decided to give it a try!  The atmosphere is definitely fun when you walk in, and it is extremely modern and a bit European-ized.We had a party of 4 and ordered a variety of dishes to share.  We started off with some guacamole and chips, and the Wahaca Selection, which included tacos, quesadillas, tostadas, and taquitios.  The tacos and taquitos were definitely the highlights of the selections, and the tostadas were forgettable.  The tortillas on the soft tacos were sooo soft!  I was definitely surprised!  We also ordered the Chicken Mole Enchiladas as well as the Pork Tacos, and everything was GREAT, and actually too much food for all of us to finish!  To be fair, I haven't had authentic Mexican food in a few months and the closest thing I've had was Chipotle in Tottenham Court Road (which is ridiculously over-priced, under-sized, and just generally sub-par), so I had nothing to really compare the food to.  But it definitely satisfied me in the moment!Afterwards, we headed downstairs where the bar is and kind of went crazy with the tequila shots and the fooseball table! I liked that there was a tequila and margaritas bar! There was lots of space and was relatively empty for a Saturday afternoon, and even though I have to say those tequila shots are kinda pricey coming from Los Angeles where tequila is basically the price of water, we had a really great time just hanging out and enjoying the chill atmosphere, and we got way too caught up in the foose-ball action to really notice anything otherwise.  We ran up a bill of about £75 for 4 people, which is a bit extreme in my opinion for four rounds.I like that all the plates at Wahaca are small and are great for sharing and tasting, and it is pretty authentic for London and I wouldn't expect anything more or less. I'll be back!

6ePijnnlxnJabWfrBPRB5A.text: I liked this place for many years after watching Masterchef winner Thomasina Miers help introduce Mexican food to the Soho scene. Was hardly around as an eaterie here. I do think the guacamole always needs more lime. Had to ask for extra a few times, but maybe that's my personal preference. I don't think the burritos are all that. They are good but Freebird is better. What I do like and what they do excel is is the tequila and the pork tacos. Both are the only things I order when I go there now. I once had 15 tacos in one sitting it was so addictive (I must have been hungry!). The Soho branch is much bigger though both have queues most of the time on weekends. But the staff are really great.

loMlwdCYTpBV_o3C1jIAIA.text: The wait took 45 minutes but at least there's a bar downstairs where you can order drinks and chips. Downside: the chips are stale and chewy :( but at least the guacamole was passable.Service is friendly but frazzled.  Food is pretty good considering it only cost 23 quid for 2 of us - but this is a far, far cry from California Mexican food...+Steak tacos-Chicken tacos+Black bean quesadilla-EsquitesAnyway, overall = not bad, I left fairly pleased.PS don't come here for a date. You'll go deaf screaming at each other over the ambient din.

KXAiuVnjk15pqBVsIi-yGw.text: Yes. I would never EVER thought I'd give a Mexican place 5 stars as I don't consider it healthy and nice, but here we go I did it. This place completely change the way I think about Mexican cuisine. It can be super fresh and healthy.The 'street food' section is absolutely amazing. Their signature pork pibilos (just ask for signature pork street dish!) with black beans and onions alone worth a visit. Fresh green & spelt salad is so delicious they must add some other (magical) ingredients to make it taste so lovely.Grilled cactus is bursting with juice as you bite into it and other food (yes, I went there on a Friday day and after a few cocktails I lost count of what we had) - is just amazing.The place has good trendy and informal ambience - so good for all sorts of occasions. Downstairs they have a bar, so if you need to wait for your table - they serve some mean tequilas down there.Oh and the service is SUPER quick and attentive. Literally as you place it, sometimes they would bring you the first food you've ordered.Coming from a person who used to say 'I don't like Mexican food' these 5 stars should really be 6.

ynS_H0yVmcokJ8e4ohK13w.text: Surprisingly it's one of the best meals I have had in London on this trip so far. The price is reasonable, the quantities are filling, and the food is delicious!To start we got the chips and guacamole: Great!I had the British Steak plate with green rice. The steak was soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo tasty. Not to mention that corn relish...My mouth is watering just thinking about it. The green rice that came with it was also mouth-watering. The dish also had soft tacos that came with it. I had a taste of their pulled pork taco, which wasn't too bad. Apparently their fish tacos and their cheese and bean quesadilla are also very good.A great bar also exists downstairs, so if you have to wait for a seat or want to stay after dinner, it is a great place to be with cool hanging chairs and fooseball tables.

O6_XFNRgh-mhyQ9E5eVg1A.text: I was in London for work not too long ago and my friend who is now a local brought me here for dinner. It was delish! I had their seasonal sweet potato cheese quesadilla (i don't remember the exact name) but it was really good. Also, we tried another vegetarian taco with plantains  - also a winner! it had a bit of a spicy kick. I must warn you without reservation the wait can be a drag. We waited a bit but had cocktails on the terrace (aka outside a storage container w a deck - such an awesome idea - maybe it's the engineer in me?) So I haven't been friends with tequila since college (but then again who has?? lol)  anyways I gave into to trying a drink at their tequila bar and I ended up having more than one! I didn't taste the tequila at all but still enjoyed the drink.btw, wahaca come to NYC!!?! please? thanks =)I almost forgot - the food truck outside is also amazing!!!

PLEg1-7F9pFV5qEOqjPWzQ.text: Hard for an American to give Mexican food a try, but we did and it was good food. It is by no means authentic, but the flavor was good and our service was not bad for how crowded it was.

hJgq7GgSP098aKEXXtIe_A.text: Every time I think I've been to all the Wahaca in London, I end up finding another! Friends and I tucked in for a Tequila Tuesday when another place fell through, and I had a great time sitting at the elevated center booth. I felt like a celebrity for our location and ability to look down on everyone else. It's not condescending when it's just where they sat you in the restaurant, right? Also the chiquita banana lamp was awesome.For food, I had a few of my normal fare: chips and guacamole, chicken taquitos, and the chipotle chicken quesadilla. They're the same standard as any other Wahaca I've been to, which is to say quite good. I also had my passionfruit maragarita to set the whole thing off.To be fair, we didn't have the greatest service, which is why I lowered this to three stars. It was super busy (for a Tuesday? or ever?) and I just felt like it took ages to get things like water, or to place our orders. There were empty tables though, and our food came out of the kitchen really quickly (like it does at all Wahacas), so I'm not sure what was going on. Otherwise, another good Wahaca experience to check off the list!

n2d_s08tUWfoyvFVqqMxIA.text: Great place for mexican food served with a modern twist right in the middle of Soho, in direct vicinity of various theaters. Service was prompt and very friendly, the menu is extensive with a large selection of "Mexican tapas". If this isn't your thing there is a selection of larger dishes to chose from, too. Quality of the food was excellent, portions were decent. However, especially on the weekends, this place will end up packed and consequently will become very noisy. Not a good spot for a romantic dinner, but a great location for a night out with friends.

2ZEaCGkNRqj8P6qTfOYAkg.text: Spontaneous catch ups are always fun. They're more fun when you choose Wahaca as your meeting place, trust me. This Mexican market style restaurant has come up around London at the perfect time. Everyone is going crazy for tapas style food right now; there's something so sociable about it, grabbing a few dishes and throwing them in the middle for everyone to pick at over wine and good quality gossip. Or the idea that you can try lots of little things and broaden your culinary horizons.Or maybe it's just my group of friends that can no longer be jealous of what anyone else is having, because we're all having the same! Whatever your motives, if you're into sharing and caring them try this place!I've been to half a dozen of these restaurants in London now, but picked this one to write my main review because it's definitely my favourite. So laidback, yet busy. So relaxed yet it feels like a treat. Of course mix this with a margarita and what's not to love! Came here with a friend at peak time, so we grabbed one of the last spots on window seats, perfect for peoplewatching (my favourite pasttime!) We split all the best yummy treats Wahaca can offer - pork pibil, tostadas, tacitos, quesadillas and some amazing smoky, spicy sweet potatoes. SO GOOD.

LU5cjrRewflVjKQao6RufA.text: Really underwhelming Mexican fare for what looked like a promising locale. While admittedly I can only comment on their winter burrito, unfortunately there isn't really very much to comment about it. It was a passable burrito, presented in a strange rectangular rather than cylindrical form, and was neither particularly favourful or memorable. However, what really annoyed me about this restaurant was their music. Oh my days, their music was annoying. Blasted out of tinny little overhead speakers (which, very conveniently happened to be right by our table), someone, at some point decided it would be a great idea to play cheese Mariachi band music... all the time. Not only cheesy, but also loud, it wouldn't be an understatement to say the music pretty much ruined my whole dining experience. In addition, their waitstaff is awful - my friend asked for her burrito without avocado, and I asked for no tortilla chips with mine. Our server assured us this could be done, and proceeded to bring us our food, avocado and tortilla chips included. Although after pointing this out they got it right the second time around, it meant we had to wait longer, and were subjected to that godawful music for longer. Needless to say, I won't be coming back here anytime soon (read: ever).

-zkljKkODyz_CfQ03uQn4g.text: This place was packed at lunch time but the food compensated the wait (a short one too). My friends and I tried two nibbles and one course meal. The taquitos were not that impressive. I thought it was filled with too much meat but it was a good 'street food' as they call it. The burrito was excellent but I couldn't finish it myself. Add some spice with their special fruity chili sauce.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken burrito and chicken taquito for lunch.

1CULfzNBjevJI-PywKP6ZA.text: I've been sold on Wahaca for about 3 years and am big fan of Tommi's approach to food. Having been a regular at the Westfield branch and always enjoyed the mostly very good food and always reasonable prices I was excited that a branch was opening near my office. I waited for it to open and visited with a colleague a soon as it did. It's really a transformation of what I'm sure used to be Cap Gemini reception. Striking and open plan it's an attractive look and really will stand our amongst it's Wardour Street competitors.The service is always cheery if occasionally overstretched. Tasty guacamole and chips are always a good place to start.I have a few regular dishes which I nearly always order and always taste the same, which in this context is positive. Chorizo and Potato Quesadilla, Chicken Taquitos, Beans with Cheese and Green Rice. All of these were great examples of what Wahaca can do, tasty, fresh. The Taquitos in particular were great, crispy, salty, cheesy, fresh, chewy and brilliant collection of textures and flavours.The downstairs bar is great addition, can never go wrong with a Hibiscus margarita whilst waiting for a table upstairs.

mEDDI5WWlEBW1upUVAo64Q.text: I'm a little bit of a Mexican food fiend. I'm a taco-shaped, burrito-stuffed, hot sauce-breathing foodie, if you will. So much so, I ate Mexican food for a week before uprooting from California and moving to London. Wow, that sounds considerably less cool than I thought it would. Anywho, Wahaca, I think, is the closest replica to the real deal as I've found in this city (but please let me know if there's a better one! I will buy you a margarita in thanks!) I slightly prefer the food truck out front as far as authentic eats go, but the plates are tasty and interesting without that try-hard feel.Highlights - I'm a big fan of the chicken tinga tacos. The hot sauces! I bought them both. The guacamole is so so so good, and two thumbs up for the hibiscus margarita. Lowlights - I would skip the cactus tacos next time, and the fish tacos were just so-so. I'd love to see them try a non-breaded fish taco. The mid-week hour-long wait for a table isn't ideal but it gives you time to grab a margarita and some guacamole and chips.Love the location - overlooking the Thames - and the shipping container structure. They said it's only supposed to stick around for 18 months, but last time I was there one of the bartenders mentioned that its popularity has them considering keeping it open for longer. Yay! PS - The seed matchbooks have produced 5 habanero plants, and I've got some promising serrano chili plants as well. Horticulture for the win!

MIW6UkuHqj733x8UaHJvtQ.text: I always enjoy a visit to a Wahaca and this time was no exception. I really liked both the restaurant and bar area here in Soho. Very cool vibes as always. I went in on a Saturday night around 9pm so I was doubtful if we were even going to get a table, but we were greeted politely at the door and given an eta of 45-60min (not too bad I thought). In the end we waited maybe 30 minutes for our table which went by so fast we didn't even have time to finish our delicious Hibiscus Mojitos in the downstairs bar before the alarm went off in our buzzer. The lady who took us to our table seemed a little rude and uninterested, but otherwise the staff was great! I absolutely love the "Street Food" section on the menu and ordered 3 things from there - all delicious and divine! You can't really go wrong here no matter what you order. The food came really fast (as it always does) even though the restaurant was fully booked. Our lovely waitress recommended the Hibiscus Margarita for me and it was ridiculously amazing, maybe even better than the Mojito. All and all the night was a success, which (to be frank) I've become to expect in a Wahaca anyway :)

Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Black bean tostadas and Sweet potato & feta taquito
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Black bean tostadas and Sweet potato & feta taquito

cvfQVH5iPRXItMK6w1ei-A.text: I visited Wahaca Southbank on Sunday evening, around 6pm. It was busier than I expected! Was given a buzzer and told there'd be an 45 minute wait, which I wasn't keen on. Waited 10 minutes at the bar (only 1 barman serving), 15 minutes later a table was available. Glad I stayed :)Service was friendly and the food came quite quickly. I had ordered steak tacos, sweet potato taquitos and black bean quesadillas. The steak was tender, quesadillas were made tastier with some of the hot and fruity sauce. There was a mix up with the order and I got the sweet potato side (looked very small, maybe 4 pieces). I asked for the taquitos instead and the waitress was swift and pleasant in rectifying this. I found the taquitos quite strange in texture (blue corn tortillas were chewy in places and crispy in others) but the taste of the sweet potato filling was delicious, and the fresh lettuce and tomato topping was fresh and perfectly complementary.Reasonably priced with small dishes and most drinks averaging at about £4 each. Service was warm and efficient. I left feeling full and satisfied but not heavy or stuffed. Would definitely recommend.

oNoZdgoF1Jj3gMgOrN3UGQ.text: Genuinely good Mexican even by California standards. Mole tacos were perfect. Pork pibil wasn't as flavorful as some I've had, but was still quite tasty and is a dish I'd order again. Also had a burrito and the combo plate amongst the group, all of which were worth ordering. Guacamole was decent but the pork cracklings that came with it more than made up for the average guac. Classic margarita was just that, simple and excellent. Lime, tequila, and triple sec.Plus a rarity in my (limited) experience in England, they had hot sauce that was actually hot!Service was attentive and generally very good. They brought a Modelo Especial rather than the requested Negro Modelo, but fixed their mistake quickly and took the less tasty Especial off the bill even though it was half gone by the time they realized the problem. Only downside to the place is you realize you're in London when the check shows up. 60GBP for 2.5 so not crazy expensive, but not Cali cheap.

MynDfDl9GY8bVwm9dYxTfg.text: This place was obviously going to be good, you can sort of tell when you walk in the place! It did not disappoint! Big bar downstairs and interesting loos. I will return !

Nak0Bc36OCE9hJeyiQ8EIA.text: Get ready for a wonderful evening with friends - book Wahace place in Soho. It is hot, it's is lively (you will hardly get in w/o the reservation, practically all evenings are busy there, it is Soho!!!), the food is great, fresh, colorful, real Mexican style, as were the cocktails. Don't drink wine here, it is not the best you could imagine and it comes in mustard glasses, phh! A special tip: A small farewell gift are not the matches, but a small pack of Serrano chillies seeds which looks like matches. Don't forget to grow Wahaca chillies in your home! Address: Wahaca - Mexican market eating - Soho London, 80 Wardour Street, London W1F OTF, +44 207 734 0195)Summary in the Czech language: Skvele misto v londynskem Soho na barevnou mexickou veceri s kamarady. Vsechno skvele, ceny OK, jen si nedavejte vino. A jako darek na rozloucenou poproste o malou cervenou krabicku - vypada jako krabicka od sirek, ale jsou v ni seminka chilli papricek!

O3m6rno54wJsI-tmt0nR-g.text: I have yet to have a bad experience at Wahaca! I started off with a Classic margarita- which is one of the best in Soho. The enchiladas suizas were out of this world. The tomatillo sauce has tons of flavour with a nice kick too.And ask for Eric as your waiter! He has a very outgoing personality and will give you great service

EW139PFjt0XmYBod_X1AXQ.text: I love Wahaca, not sure if I am a fan of this location though... or what I ordered.  I know that solo diners can be a pain to seat, but the location wasn't THAT busy and I was relegated to the bar style table against the window with bar stools.  I think that it also had an effect on the service I got because my back was to everything and I had to turn around each time to get a waiter's attention.I ordered the pork burrito... I figured I loved the pork tacos, so the burrito should be nice.  I also ordered a side of the roasted sweet potatoes.  The sweet potatoes are fantastic and a MUST!  The tortilla chips on my plate were stale and could have used more pico de gallo.  The burrito... well the pork was lovely and I love the pickled onions (beware they do have a spicy kick to them), but combining them with the black beans and green rice didn't do it for me.  The nice thing is that the burrito is so big, that I cut it open and picked what I wanted and still managed to get full.  I think the Covent Garden location is still my favourite and I think the sharing plates are better options!

efg4WyJoQx_876LbrNczng.text: I'm from Texas so I was definitely curious to see how Wahaca would compare to the Tex-Mex and Mexican food I'm used to from home. I tried the pork pibil tacos, the black beans & cheese quesadilla, and a margarita. I LOVED the pork pibil tacos. They were the perfect size and all of the flavors worked really well together. The black beans & cheese quesadilla was not the greatest...really plain and boring and it definitely lacked flavor. I was not the biggest  fan of the margarita either...I couldn't finish it! I think it was a bit too strong.Overall I had a pretty good experience there and would go back the next time I'm in London to get more of those pork tacos!

GccZuk-WKjdzMC2RxsKd6Q.text: Not feeling the love for this place anymore.The first couple of times I went to Wahaca I was blown away but since then it hasn't quite lived up to my expectations.  That said most people I bring love it so maybe I am just a little harder to impress these days.I went back there last night and went to the Soho branch.  We had to wait over an hour for a table but it was our choice to wait.  The bar area here is better than in some of the others as there are tables and seats.  The cocktails as always were fantastic - I credit Wahaca with completely reforming my opinion on Tequila!By the time we got to sit down it was nearly 10 o'clock and as a result I think we had lost our appetites a bit.  The service as always was good and the food came quickly but we ordered too much and couldn't finish it.   There were a few items that I wasn't too keen on and nothing that really blew me away.   It was my friend's first time at Wahaca and he didn't seem that excited about it either.   It didn't help that we saw a mouse scuttling across the floor just before we left. - shudders!Sorry Wahaca but I think I've fallen out of love with you.

rMcHz7-RH00xtQ1NAsnw-A.text: I like corn tacos and sweet potatoes ... Waiters are nice. Also they have kids menu.my daughter enjoys juice and vegetables.

okdfbDOi2RoX4t0Qi9BjiA.text: Amazing service.. Loved the decor and music..the beef and pork tacos were amazing and I also enjoyed the salmon tostadas.. Make sure you sip on the tequila as recommended..don Julio

eXI_PVy5_BN2G1d6DN3KSA.text: This is my favourite Wahaca. The food is as excellent as in any other Wahaca, the views across the river Thames are beautiful and the restaurant itself is made of containers - can't beat that! However, you will have an hour wait for a table so just one if you are not really hungry and have time to spare.

luMKsPLheHj8fdRNkjPSjQ.text: average food, small portons. i dont see the fuss t always is busy.

Ludvsfmh0qinw5MPEkFFow.text: Good food great service and for a short time only on the special menu chapulines fundido thats Mexican crickets to you and me.  With onions chilli's  and cheese, try if your brave!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Decor

vC2Itl9ziK0CmlKU-Su70g.text: If you're after a quick bite for lunch or after work, look no further than Wahaca. I may be slightly biased, being a big Mexican fan, but it never disappoints. For a bit of variety, try a selection of smaller dishes from the street food menu - I recommend the chicken tostada!All in all, the food is delicious, it comes almost criminally quickly, and it can all be washed down with a tasty mojito (try the hibiscus). What's not to like?

gtpxY0hcvrMTBFzSkxYgaA.text: Love this restaurant!  Great view of the river if you get a table upstairs, and they never rush you out despite usually having a line at peak hours.  The sampler is great - tacos are very well crafted, and quesadillas are perfect.  Their guac is great, but not the best.  Avocado and corn salad is fantastic.  They don't have the mini burritos that are so great at their other locations and the prices are a bit higher here than their others due to what I imagine is a costlier spot to run a restaurant.  Typically a great atmosphere and the food is worth the money.  Only 4 instead of 5 stars because of price and the fact that it's not quite as good as their other locations.

vnwyKqaOf_b5MvE6xZO18g.text: Amazing interior design , the avocado salad was great , sweet potato was good , guacamole not nice at all full of onion , we order the steak tacos not good , the service is poor , I like the place only  .

Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

8teF2MdAdn6n5OM4_Yoz2A.text: After almost three years of living in London, I finally made it to a Wahaca. In my head I imagined it to be terrible because there are several locations, but I still wanted to try it. I also thought it would be terrible as the people who own it clearly don't know how to spell Oaxaca, and when I lived in the states I had lovely experiences at an authentic Oaxacan restaurant, so I just figured it wouldn't meet my expectations. So the food. We ordered a lot of stuff. All the tacos, the guacamole with pork scratchings, the beans and chips, two types of quesadilla and some taquitos. I was actually quite impressed with the flavors of all of them. It was extremely tasty. The drinks though, left a lot to be desired. They just seemed a bit well, weak. We ordered a round at the bar to start, and those were nice, but after that they just all fell flat. So that was disappointing. The service was also disappointing. We ordered food and drinks and the server never came back it seemed. I had to stop her once for more napkins and we had to stop her again to order more of their less than stellar drinks.The other thing that frightened me is that Nava wanted to try one of the sauces. She shook it up, and went to open it and somehow it was under amazing pressure because it sprayed everywhere. It was a bit strange. So she sealed  it back up and cleaned up (hence the extra napkins). I decided to give it another go, and I opened it (this time holding a napkin over the top of the bottle) and it still sprayed. Then to my dismay, the sauce started bubbling out of the top of the bottle like the bottle was some sort of volcano. I put the bottle down, but more and more sauce was spilling out of the top. What kind of hot sauce does that? Had it gone bad? I don't know, but it frightened me and I definitely didn't try it after that.So given the lack of alcohol in the drinks and the exploding hot sauce incident and the lack of service, Wahaca won't be back on my list of places to return. But if you want to try a London chain with better than average Mexican food, give it a whirl.

fqKmVrYuvD-LmLv1iEQqwg.text: The lunch-break taco menu is very consistent, and calls for a good siesta right after. It's spicy, obviously, and maybe all the spices hides the taste of the sauce but overall I really enjoyed my tacos!The service is great too.

lkgZPReWVf-4DCif_2zUcA.text: Not the best Mexican food in the world - not even in London - but you get very much value for money. Try their flavorful combinations for example as a taco, a quesadilla or as a burrito. Everything is filling. I also like the atmosphere a lot.

w_TFBfv1GGC3V3eXLvGtaw.text: Ate here with the family on Saturday. quick tips: the food is very good value; Street food is done very innovatively using their British sourced ingredients, especially the meat based tacos. Bursting with flavor.The tequila sampler for £10 is excellent although the blanco was underwhelming and rather unrefined. The fish main course with green rice was a little underwhelming too. Sit towards the wall: the ropes are extremely comfy to lean against
